item.title: Principles of translation
item.description: Because this is the beginning The purpose in preparing this translation is to faithfully update the American Standard Version of Mark into contemporary spoken American‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Because this is the beginning The purpose in preparing this translation is to faithfully update the American Standard Version of Mark into contemporary spoken American English as used by those who don‚Äôt already know anything of the Bible, have no theology background, and are generally unfamiliar with church culture.

If you do not have a technical background in Bible translation and are still interested, read on. I will do my best to remain understandable for you too but some of the following will necessarily use scholarly language in order to communicate as clearly as possible with scholars.

More technically‚Ä¶ The Beginning of Life is an updated translation of the book of Mark. It is a direct derivative work of the American Standard Version and the World English Bible (WEB) translations of the Bible. The WEB is itself a partial update of the American Standard Version translation.

Overall principles of translation In preparing this translation, I have drawn on the underlying Greek and/or Hebrew, the rest of the Bible, other modern English translations of the Bible, and scholarly input.

The translation is heavily biased toward formal equivalance in vocabulary, resorting to dynamic equivalence when necessary. When dynamic equivalence is used to translate a technical term, the formal equivalent and/or traditional translation is preserved as a side note next to the text. I have used this and other typographical conventions to help with readability while maintaining accuracy.

Formally-equivalent word orderings are preferred but this is heavily in tension with this work‚Äôs readability goals. I have included detailed explanations about various ways I resolve this tension below.

Typographical conventions Here is an exhaustive list of these conventions: [^{-} These owe a great debt to the work of Edward Tufte]

Here is some textThis is a study note with context helpful for understanding the text. that might benefit from additional context.

A theme from this thing.Describes what happens in the text immediately following. Typeset as a header (in a lighter typeface than the text).

Translation note.Traditional, alternative, or more literal ways to translate a word or phrase. (Avoids textual criticism because of the audience.) Used especially when the translation resorts to dynamic equivalence in order to keep itself honest.

1¬†Verse 1, etc.

Cross reference,Jhn 1:1-14 hyperlinked to the NLT translation on bible.com. Used to:

  • Link to Old Testament passages when they are quoted or alluded to.
  • Link to other Bible passages that further explain what Mark is saying and/or offer context regarding the current topic in the text.

Typographical challenges The underlying text is maintained in plain text files using an extended Markdown-derived markup language.

Currently the only drawback of this format is that it offers no way to properly typeset poetry, render ‚Äúacolon‚Äù and ‚Äúbcolon‚Äù lines, etc. These are currently typeset as a blockquote using line breaks to separate poetry sections from each other.

Principles of English style This work seeks to render Mark‚Äôs gospel in modern spoken English in a colloquial and yet reverent style. Here are some examples of what this means to this author:

  • Shorter sentences, fragments.
  • It‚Äôs okay to start a sentence with a connector.
  • And contractions are okay too.

I am currently targeting a 9th or 10th grade (US) reading level.

Word ordering and formal vs. dynamic equivalence

At best, Greek word ordering is bad English style to native English speakers and is confusing to understand at worst. This reworking should respect principles of excellent English style while retaining the academic rigor present in the original ASV text.

The result should be immediately understandable by unchurched or lightly-churched individuals without eliminating challenges faced by all faithful interpreters of the Bible.

Offensive or confusing things Jesus said and did are retained and not explained. Metaphors that Jesus or Mark used are retained because these add depth and dimension to their context that otherwise would be lost. Also, many symbols and metaphors appear in a remarkably consistent way throughout the Bible so this author believes that retaining the symbols and metaphors is important to developing a cohesive understanding of the entire Bible.

Detailed notes on formal versus dynamic equivalence The ASV is a formal equivalence translation. Retain this rigor in the update within the structure of what would be considered excellent (if colloquial, spoken) English style. On the other hand, all translation work necessarily has an element of interpretation‚Äìparticularly when a word in the source language does not have a direct equivalent in the target language. In these situations, switch to dynamic equivalence while remaining as close to formal equivalence as possible.

These goals can be in tension with each other. The following principles guide how I have resolved these tensions. I‚Äôve included specific examples where needed to clearly explain a thought.

  • Retain Mark‚Äôs ‚Äúoveruse‚Äù of the word ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù. It is this author‚Äôs belief that Mark is intentionally using repetition to make a point.
  • When a global mechanical search-and-replace update works, use it to retain continuity with the underlying Greek when possible. For example: Behold ‚Üí Look!, wilderness ‚Üí desert, multitude ‚Üí large crowd; great multitude ‚Üí very large crowd., etc.
  • When appropriate, change to active voice. For example, in 1:26: ‚ÄúThe unclean spirit convulsed the man, shrieked loudly, and came out of him.‚Äù
  • Simplify wording of lists to modern spoken English standards. 1:26 above is an example of this.
  • A single thought gets a single sentence. Closely-related thoughts or those utilizing parallelism get a single sentence with semicolons separating each thought.
  • Break up excessively long sentances. But be careful to retain relative emphasis among thoughts present in the original.
  • Used sparingly, sometimes sentance fragments can be effective as long as they don‚Äôt change the relative emphasis between the idea in the fragment and the run-on sentance being broken up.
  • Many times the English is confusing because Mark used pronouns excessively or the referent of an expression is unclear without carefully studying the grammar of the context. While this may be the way Mark wrote, this is not considered high-quality spoken or written English. Resolve pronouns and other referents to their antecedents when doing this yields a clearer and equally-accurate reading.
  • Use parentheses and hyphens (as appropriate) when a thought is interrupted by another one. Prefer using punctuation over rearranging word order.
  • Rearrange word order only judiciously and being careful to preserve the emphases each individual idea in a sentence receives.
  • If a direct or indirect object is separated from its referent, rearrange the word order to bring them together.
  • For example, 2:14: As he passed by the tax office, he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus working there. Here the ASV (and the Greek) separates ‚Äúpassed by‚Äù from its indirect object ‚Äúthe tax office‚Äù with an interjection about Jesus meeting Levi there. Putting the IO next to its verb makes the sentence immediately more comprehensible to a modern reader and also clarifies the fact that Levi was a tax collector. This also clarifies the following story beginning in verse 18, without adding or removing from what was said.
  • Don‚Äôt translate symbols or metaphors. The Bible expects a lot of its reader and that‚Äôs ok. See above.
  • If a thing would be obvious to one of Mark‚Äôs original readers but not to a modern reader, clarify it using rewording, a parenthetical comment, hyphens, etc. Add a sidenote to preserve accountability.
  • Translate technical theological terms whenever necessary for comprehension among today‚Äôs largely-unchurched youth.
  • Start with the Greek literal translation. Sometimes this directly offers an excellent substitute. For example in 1:4, baptize ‚Üí ceremonially immerse [in water].
  • Consider the immediate context. For example, Mark uses the word baptize in two ways: the ceremonial way described above and also when preaching baptism [of repentance for the forgiveness of sins]. This latter case can borrow from the context immediately preceeding combined with appropriate translation sidenotes: need to immerse their affections[^ *a baptism] in God‚Äôs straight paths instead of their ownof repentance.* See below for more examples.
  • Consider the weight of Scripture. Sometimes another scripture provides an excellent explanation or definition. Continuing in verse 4, ‚Äúa baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.‚Äù Here ‚Äúsins‚Äù is used in general sense, so we need a concise, faithful expression describing ‚Äúsin‚Äù in the general sense. Here we can still let Scripture interpret Scripture by rendering this as ‚Äúforgiven for preferring selfish pleasure (and the hurt that this causes) instead‚Äù along with a cross-reference to James 4:1-3 from where this idea was directly lifted.

More discussion about translating technical theological terms Repent / repentance: These words aren‚Äôt used at all in modern spoken English and especially not among our unchurched youth.

Sin: In colloquial English, this word simply means ‚Äúa bad thing‚Äù or ‚Äúa bad person‚Äù. But in common use today when the word is used at all it is frequently used in an ironic or sarcastic way. The effect is to change ‚Äúsin‚Äù from an undesirable to a desirable thing‚Äîand sometimes even makes fun of the whole concept of sin to begin with.

Theologically this is beyond inaccurate. Further, we would rarely-to-never refer to someone as a ‚Äúsinner‚Äù in spoken English in the Bible sense of the word outside a church (or even inside most churches). As a result, this author believes the word ‚Äúsin‚Äù has completely lost its meaning in spoken English.

Other concerns happen because different parts of languages change differently over time so some English words‚Äô meaning may still be largely faithful but need elaboration or careful adjustment.

In some of these cases I have felt it more appropriate to include the theological term used in the text, but with a (usually parenthetical) elaboration or explanation in the context. Sometimes I‚Äôve used a sidenote to clarify the original authorial intent when retaining a traditional rendering.

In other cases, I have found that an English word that is closely related to or derived from the original word that hasn‚Äôt yet lost its Bible meaning and connotation.

For example, our culture‚Äôs understanding of faith is more-or-less accurate‚Äìbut only if one disregards that atheists and many scientists believe that faith is fundamentally an irrational or unscientific thing.

Consequently, I believe that perhaps the word faith itself may not be wise to use in a modern English translation. However, in common use words derived from faith remain faithful to the Bible meaning, and in many cases we can faithfully use those to substitute for and/or to clarify in situations where faith is called for.

item.content:encoded:
Post-Christian America My experience speaking with others of my generation (commonly known as generation X) about the Bible and about Christianity has been that, most people are aware of the Bible meanings of theological words and ideas as presented in modern translations.

For example, people in my generation generally know what a Christian means when s/he uses words like ‚Äúsin‚Äù, ‚Äúrepent‚Äù, ‚Äúrighteous‚Äù, ‚ÄúSatan‚Äù, ‚Äúevil spirit, unclean spirit, demon‚Äù, etc. And many in my generation have a cultural understanding of the Good News‚Äìat least enough to be innoculated to it and have their preconceived reasons for rejecting it. That is the bad news.

However, the good news for my generation is that many who are hungry to know the God of the Bible already have the required background to understand the Bible using many of the excellent modern translations.

On the other hand (in my own experience) many from the younger generation that is coming of age right now have none of this background understanding of theological terms needed to become a disciple of Jesus.

This is both an opportunity and a challenge.

The hunger In my experience, I have never met a group of people more hungry to know about God generally and the God of the Bible specifically than this younger generation. I regularly experience members of this generation immediately ask me to teach them how to know God as soon as they learn that I am a Christian.

The challenge Unfortunately, my experience has also been that when they try to read modern Bible translations these same people quickly bog down in technical theological terms like those listed above and lose interest. Forcing technical theological terms on new disciples of Jesus right at the beginning of their walk in my own experience has proven profoundly counter-productive to the Church‚Äôs mission to make disciples of Jesus Christ.

The opportunity Mark‚Äôs stated objective at the start of his book is to present ‚Äúthe beginning of the Good News of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.‚Äù

And I believe that if we take Mark‚Äôs word as gospel (inspired by the Holy Spirit) this offers a simple, straightforward, and direct way to become a true disciple of Jesus Christ as well as to make disciples of Jesus Christ as he commanded.

The Romans Road, the four spiritual laws, along with programs like Evangelism Explosion and others have borne fruit. Many have found their way to becoming a disciple of Jesus through these synopses of the Good News.

But I believe that starting with Mark (because he alone claims to start at the beginning) and studying sequentially and inductively offers a more direct road into Jesus the Truth, Christ the Door, Jesus the Way, and Jesus the Life. This approach depends simply on obtaining a faithful translation of Mark that itself translates these theological and/or cultural terms into understandable colloquial spoken English that any random native English speaker would readily comprehend.

I haven‚Äôt been able to find others with this vision, so I am beginning this work myself, in the open, hoping that others with skillsets complimenting my own offer their own expertise. And hoping that in the end this work becomes an effort representative of the Body of Christ herself and her mission to effectively make disciples of Jesus before the last day comes.

My own skillset I became a disciple of Jesus Christ as a middle-schooler and have been a passionate student of the Bible since. While I have experienced seasons during which my strength or my total commitment to Jesus has faltered, I have never let go of my fundamental profound desire to be a disciple of Jesus and a student of the Bible.

I am not a Hebrew or Greek scholar but my wife is a Biblical Hebrew scholar and I‚Äôm not afraid of Greek interlinears and/or Hebrew/Greek lexicons. These are a regular part of my personal study of the Scriptures.

Regarding Bible translation, I served a summer internship with Wycliffe Bible Translators as a high school student, grew up in the same church as Ken Taylor who originally updated the ASV‚Äìthe result being published as The Living Bible paraphrase. I am a friendly acquaintance of Mark Taylor (Ken‚Äôs son), and am familiar with many of the theological and political considerations surrounding a ‚Äúlayperson‚Äù updating an existing translation and having it remain properly a trustworthy translation instead of a ‚Äúmere paraphrase.‚Äù

My main personal weakness is that I have very little background in textual criticism, and while I understand some fundamental principles such as ‚Äúthe ‚Äòharder reading‚Äô more likely being original‚Äù I cannot hope to evaluate alternate renderings myself the way a scholar with this training could. To remediate this deficiency, I am relying on scholarly textual notes in the NET Bible 2.0, other study Bibles, and other readily-available scholarly resources. And if any of these suggest an alternate rendering to be more accurate than the traditional ASV translation, I‚Äôll cite my source(s)‚Äìprobably in a footnote but this is undecided as this concern has yet to present itself.

Naturally, if a scholar with experience in Bible translation and (particularly with) expertise in textual criticism wishes to help address any possible weaknesses I bring in this area, I would be delighted to collaborate.

item.content:encoded:
The beginning of the Good News of Jesus Here is not a baby in a manger. Here is not a child who wise kings searched for with gifts. Instead, Mark is laser-focused on:

  • Introducing his reader to Jesus.
  • Explaining Jesus‚Äôs purpose for coming.
  • Inviting his reader to make a conscious choice based on this information.

How? Here is a summary of the choices Mark invites his reader to make:

  1. To admit that our life‚Äôs paths haven‚Äôt always been straight. Sometimes they have been crooked. The first thing, then, is to straighten our paths as much as we know how to do. Apologize to anyone we have wronged and do whatever is needed to make it right. Apologize‚Äìmost of all‚Äìto God whose loving principles we have disregarded, preferring selfish pleasure instead. Mrk 1:1 to Mrk 1:6
  2. To recognize Jesus as the Ruler‚Äìand invite him to be our own ruler too. Mrk 1:3
  3. To know Jesus as King‚Äìand to pledge our allegiance to him. Mrk 1:15

Conclusion These are difficult things to ask anyone to consider. The rest of Mark‚Äôs book offers the information we need to decide how we will respond.

As you read, I encourage you to expectantly trust that God will help you to understand and will help you know how to respond.

8¬†Immediately Jesus perceived in his spirit that they reasoned silently this way so he asked them, ‚ÄúWhy do you question and criticize? 9¬†Which is easier to tell a paralyzed person: ‚ÄòYour sins are forgiven‚Äô or, ‚ÄòGet up, pick up your bed, and walk?‚Äô

Everyone was amazed; they spoke with soaring words about God!or: glorified God ‚ÄúWe have never seen anything like this!‚Äù they said.üîë Religious Tradition now has a choice: will they accept Jesus‚Äôs kingly authority as superior to their current religious understanding or will they oppose him? Those of us with religious traditions have the same choice.

Jesus is close to people who recognize their own need‚Ä¶ 13¬†Jesus returned to the seashore; a very large crowd came together, and Jesus taught them. 14¬†As he passed the tax office, he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus working there. ‚ÄúFollow me,‚Äù Jesus said. And Levi got up and followed him.

15¬†Later, Jesus was reclining at the meal table in Levi‚Äôs house, and many other tax collectors and socially unacceptable ‚Äúsinners‚Äù sat down with Jesus and his students;disciples there were many of these kinds of people, and they followed Jesus.

‚Ä¶But Religious Tradition is offended by Jesus‚Äôs openness toward people who know their hearts are sick 16¬†But the religious experts who were scribes and conservative teachers known as Pharisees questioned Jesus‚Äôs studentsdisciples when they saw him eating with the ‚Äúsinners‚Äù and tax collectors.

‚ÄúWhy does Jesus eat and drink with tax collectors and ‚Äòsinners‚Äô?‚Äù these respected religious teachers asked Jesus‚Äôs students.disciples

17¬†Overhearing this, Jesus replied, ‚ÄúThose who are healthy don‚Äôt need a doctor, but sick people do. I didn‚Äôt come to call people who think they are right in God‚Äôs sight,the ‚Äòrighteous‚Äô, but Jesus is being sarcastic but people who ultimately prefer pursuing selfish pleasuresinners to recognize the hurt that this choice causes and to have a deep, profound change of heart.‚Äùto repentance

Religious tradition is blind to who Jesus is‚Ä¶ 18¬†John‚Äôs studentsdisciples and some Pharisees‚Äìreligious Conservatives‚Äìwere fasting by temporarily going without something to instead focus more clearly on God. They came to Jesus and questioned, ‚ÄúWhy do John‚Äôs studentsdisciples and the Pharisees‚Äô studentsdisciples fast, but your studentsdisciples don‚Äôt fast?‚Äù

19¬†Jesus answered, ‚ÄúCan the honored groomsmen at a wedding deprive themselves while the bridegroom is with them? As long as they have the bridegroom with them, they can‚Äôt fast. 20¬†But the days will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, and beginning that day they will fast.

21¬†üîë To escape religious tradition, a person needs a new covering for one‚Äôs naked shame and flexibility to receive the new wine. The new clothes and the flexibility to receive the new wine are obtained by choosing the Ruler‚Äôs roads over our own selfish cultural preferences and accepting God‚Äôs forgiveness with expectant trust. The new wine itself (that causes us to grow) is obtained by hearing and applying Jesus‚Äôs teaching.‚ÄúNobody patches an old shrunken piece of clothes using new fabric that hasn‚Äôt shrunk yet. Otherwise when the new patch shrinks, it will tear away from the old cloth; it will make a worse hole than before. 22¬†No one puts new wine into old (brittle) wine-skins; otherwise when the new wine ferments it will expand, cause the old skins to burst, the wine to pour out, and the wine-skins to be destroyed. Instead, they put new wine into fresh wine-skins.‚Äùüîë Jesus reaches out to all those whose religious traditions get in the way of God‚Äôs Kingdom in their lives‚Äìand explains how to escape. The sheer number of stories Mark tells about this topic indicates how difficult this can be.

‚Ä¶But those who recognize their hunger are filled 23¬†On the Sabbath day Jesus and his studentsdisciples were going through some grain fields and his studentsdisciples began to pick ears of grain to eat.Lev 19:9-10The Law of Moses explicitly permitted poor people to eat grain from the corners of others‚Äô fields.

24¬†‚ÄúLook! why do they do what is against (traditional religious) law on the sacred Sabbath day?‚Äù these religious ConservativesPharasees objected.

And do you remember how it is against the Law of Moses for anyone to eat the temple bread except for the priests‚Äìbut David ate it and gave some to those who were with him too?‚Äù 1Sa 21:1-6

27¬†Jesus said to them,üîë These religious conservatives were unwilling to be flexible about their traditional laws, much less learn how to apply the Law of Moses correctly from Jesus. Ultimately, their allegiance was to their own Religious ‚ÄúKingdom‚Äù and its earthly political power instead of to God‚Äôs kingdom. ‚ÄúThe special Sabbath day was made to meet people‚Äôs needs, not men and women for the Sabbath. 28¬†Therefore the Son of Man is The Ruler, even over the Sabbath!‚Äù

Jesus heals a man‚Äôs deformed hand on the sacred Sabbath day‚Ä¶ 1¬†Jesus entered the synagogue again, and a man was there whose hand was deformed.

‚ÄúDoes the Lawe.g.: the Law of Moses found in the books of Exodus through Deuteronomy intend for a person to do good to others or to harm others on the Sabbath day? To save a life or to kill?‚Äù Jesus asked.üîë Jesus offers his enemies another opportunity to change‚Äìto accept the good news of his kingdom with expectant trust.

His enemies were silent.

5¬†Jesus looked around at them with anger (out of grief because his enemies‚Äô hearts were becoming harder and harder), then said to the man, ‚ÄúStretch out your hand.‚Äù The man stretched it out and his hand was restored as healthy as the other.

‚Ä¶But the religious Conservatives preferred the man stay disabled 6¬†The religious ConservativesPharasees left and immediately conspired against Jesus with the ‚ÄúPro King Herod‚Äù political party;Herodians together they began planning to kill him.Herod was the corrupt puppet king installed by Rome to rule over Israel.üîë Religious preferences can be a form of selfish comfort‚Äìa comfort that we are ‚Äúright‚Äù and others are ‚Äúwrong.‚Äù If allowed to be more important than Jesus himself, these preferences and convictions will ultimately kill God‚Äôs kingdom in our lives.

The followers: people who liked Jesus 7¬†Jesus went back to the sea with his students;disciples a huge crowd followed him from Galilee, from Judea, 8¬†from Jerusalem, from Idumaea, from beyond the Jordan, and from the area around Tyre and Sidon. When Jesus arrived, an enormous crowd gathered made up of people who had heard about the amazing things Jesus was doing.

The students: people who joined Jesus, who learned, and who helped 9¬†Jesus asked his studentsapprentices or disciples to keep a little boat nearby because of the crowd pressing toward him.

10¬†Jesus had healed many and those who had diseases pressed toward him; they were trying to touch him.

11¬†The evil spirits (whenever they saw Jesus) fell down before him shouting, ‚ÄúYou are the Son of God!‚Äù 12¬†But Jesus sternly warned them not to tell people who he was.

The twelve: people who spoke for Jesus with his authority 13¬†Jesus climbed a mountain and called to those he wanted. And they came.

14¬†He appointed twelve:üîë Everyone Jesus calls close to himself is important, and he knows them by name. to be close to him, to send out and speak God‚Äôs word, 15¬†and to have authority to heal sicknesses and cast out demons:

16¬†Simon, to whom he gave the name Peter; 17¬†James the son of Zebedee; and John, the brother of James, (whom he called Boanerges, which means, Sons of Thunder); 18¬†Andrew; Philip; Bartholomew; Matthew; Thomas; James, the son of Alphaeus; Thaddaeus; Simon the Zealot; 19¬†and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed him.

Those outside and those inside Then Jesus came to his home.

20¬†The large crowd gathered together again, so that those inside could not eat bread.

21¬†When Jesus‚Äôs friends heard the news they came to take custody of him; they said, ‚ÄúHe is insane!‚Äù

22¬†The religious leaders who were scribes from Jerusalem said, ‚ÄúHe has BeelzebulBeelzebul was the name gentile nations used for Satan, the chief demon. inside him!‚Äù and, ‚ÄúHe casts out demons using power the ruler of the demons gave him!‚Äù

23¬† Jesus called for them.

Using illustrationsparables to make his point Jesus asked, ‚ÄúHow can SatanLit: accuser or plaintiff; the chief demon cast out Satan?

  • 24¬†If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom can‚Äôt stand.
  • 25¬†If a familyhouse fights against itself, that family will break apart.
  • 26¬†If Satansee note on verse 23 rebels against himself and is divided he can‚Äôt stand. He is finished!
  • 27¬†Nobody can enter the Strong Man‚Äôs house and ransack it unless he first ties up the Strong Man; then he can ransack his house.

28¬†‚ÄúI say with certainty: all of peoples‚Äô selfish intentions and actions will be forgiven, including flagrant disrespectblasphemy with which they may defameblaspheme God.

29¬†‚ÄúBut whoever deliberately defames and slandersblasphemes (actions performed by) the Holy Spirit never has forgiveness;üîë Inflexible Religious Tradition is an enemy of God‚Äôs Kingdom. If allowed to live in one‚Äôs heart it ultimately kills. their guilt never ends.‚Äù 30¬†‚Äîbecause the religious leaders said, ‚ÄúA demon owns him.‚Äù

31¬†The mother and brothers of Jesus came. Standing outside, they sent for Jesus and called to him.

32¬†A large crowd was sitting around Jesus, and they told him, ‚ÄúLook! your mother, your brothers, and your sisters are outside looking for you.‚Äùüîë Mark has described the inflexibly religious, the casual followers, the students, and the twelve. Which kind of person are you most like right now? If you want to join Jesus, all he requires is that you set your affections on the things God wants and that you do these things as best as you know how right now. He will take care of the rest. Can you do that much? Ask Jesus and he will help.

item.content:encoded:
The teaching to understand all the other teachings 1¬†Jesus returned to the seaside to teach. A huge crowd gathered, so Jesus got into a boat in the water and sat down; the crowd listened from the land nearby.

2¬†Jesus taught the crowd many things using word-pictures as illustrations. Speaking urgently, Jesus began to teach:

3¬†‚ÄúCarefully listen and see:‚ÄùLit: spoke saying ‚ÄòListen! Look! ‚Ä¶

The illustration of the seed and the soil ‚ÄúA farmer went out to plant.‚Äù

  • 4¬†‚ÄúAs he spread his seeds some fell next to the road; the birds came and ate them.
  • 5¬†‚ÄúOther seeds fell on rocky ground where there was little soil. Immediately plants sprang up (because the soil wasn‚Äôt deep) but 6¬†when the sun rose it scorched the seed. Because the seed‚Äôs roots had no depth the plants withered away.
  • 7¬†‚ÄúOther seeds fell among thorns and the thorns grew up and choked them; they didn‚Äôt yield any fruit.
  • 8¬†‚ÄúOther seeds fell into good soil, grew to maturity, and yielded fruit. Some produced thirty times, some sixty times, and some one hundred times as much as was originally planted.

9¬†‚ÄúIf anyone‚Äôs heart is open to hear, that person must carefully listen!‚ÄùIf anyone has ‚Äòears to hear‚Äô let him hear

Jesus explains his illustrations to those who stay with him 10¬†Later‚Äìafter the crowds left Jesus alone‚Äìthose who lingered with him,those around him along with the twelve, asked him to explain this illustration.

11¬†Jesus replied, ‚ÄúGod has given you the mysteries of his Kingdom;To you has been given the mysteries of God‚Äôs kingdom I only offer illustrations to those who are outside it. 12¬†This is so that

While seeing they may ‚Äúsee‚Äù but not perceive,Jer 5:21-29Ezk 12:2-3

And while hearing they may ‚Äúhear‚Äù and not understand;

Otherwise they might turn around,

And their selfish preferences and choices be forgiven.‚Äù

13¬†Jesus continued, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you understand this illustration?üîë e.g.: This illustration is the key to understanding the rest of Jesus‚Äôs teachings. If not, how will you understand all the other ones?‚Äù

The Word is beyond value and everything that detracts from it is destructive 14¬†‚ÄúThe farmer spreads the Word.‚ÄùIn Jesus‚Äôs day farmers scattered seeds across the ground; it would be normal for seed to land elsewhere than in the field.

  • 15¬†The first are peopleThese are beside the road where the Word is spread; when they hear‚Ä¶ who are beside the road where the word is spread!üîë The farmer‚Äôs plow can break the most hardened dirt road so it can receive the seed. When they hear the Word, immediately Satan comes and takes1) to steal the Word that the farmer planted in them.
  • 16¬†The next seeds landed on shallow rocky soil.üîë The farmer can dig out the rocks that prevent roots from going deep. When people are shallow rocky soil and hear the Word they immediately receive it with delight! 17¬†But the Word‚Äôs roots cannot grow deep in their hearts and they only live a short time. When they begin to experience trouble or hostility because they received the Word, immediately they are bitterly offended and leave.2) to kill
  • 18¬†Other seeds land among thorns.üîë The farmer can dig out the thorny distractions that ultimately scratch us, entangle us, and destroy the Word. When people are thorny soil, they hear the Word‚Äìbut other things in their lives present themselves as alternatives to the Word. 19¬†The world‚Äôs distractions are one alternative. The mirage of being satisfied by material things,deceitfulness of wealth is another. Being preoccupied with other things is another alternative to the Word. These things all crowd out the Word and cause it to be unfruitful!3) to destroy the Word‚Äôs fruitfulness
  • 20¬†But there is seed that lands on good ground.üîë We all begin as unfruitful soil. But the farmer is capable of making each kind of unfruitful soil healthy. When we are made healthy in these ways, the natural result is expectant trust that the seed will grow, mature, and bear fruit‚Äìso we welcome it gladly into our hearts. These people hear the Word, accept it, and are fertile soil bearing fruit. Some of these people multiply the Word thirty times, some sixty times, and some one hundred times beyond what they received!‚Äù4) life, rich and satisfyingJhn 10:10

It‚Äôs God‚Äôs privilege to conceal things and the king‚Äôs privilege to discover them 21¬†Jesus continued, ‚ÄúIs an oil lamp brought to a placeüîë A basket‚Äôs purpose is to help with human labor; a bed‚Äôs purpose is to aid our rest. The light doesn‚Äôt belong under either one, but in its own rightful place. in order to be put under a basket or under a bed? Isn‚Äôt it put on a stand?

22¬†‚ÄúNothing is hidden except for it to be discovered, and every secret is intended to be illuminated.Pro 25:2

23¬†‚ÄúIf anyone‚Äôs heart is open to hear, that person should carefully listen!‚ÄùIf anyone has ‚Äòears to hear‚Äô‚Ä¶

Value it, use it, and be generously given more‚Äìotherwise lose it 24¬†Jesus said, ‚ÄúPay careful attention to what you hear! The metric you use to measure what you apply to your life will also be used to measure more back to you‚Äìalong with a gracious bonus.and extra to you.

25¬†Whoever makes what they hear part of themselves will be given more. But the person who ignores what they hear,e.g.: so it‚Äôs as if they don‚Äôt know it at all even what that person genuinely has will be taken away.‚Äùüîë How do we make the teachings Jesus has offered so far part of ourselves? Start with the three kinds of unfruitful soil above and apply each lesson to the degree you know how right now. Here are some thoughts to get you started:1) What habits or well-worn paths keep you from hearing Jesus‚Äôs Word to begin with? What attitudes keep you doing or thinking things you know are harmful? List these and pray, asking God to help you change. Then make a plan and begin changing. Find someone else who can support you and keep you accountable.2) Are you aware of any things you do that are unhealthy or harmful toward yourself or others? If you are unwilling to change these things, they become like the stones that keep Jesus‚Äôs Word from taking root in your heart. List these. Leave no stone unturned. Ask God for forgiveness. If you have harmed somebody else, do whatever you are able to do to make it right and ask for their forgiveness too.3) Lastly, what things are you passionate about? Being passionate toward something isn‚Äôt bad by itself. But it‚Äôs bad if you begin to love it more than you love Jesus so that you stop paying attention to Jesus and his Word. Ask God for help and begin placing healthy boundaries on these things. Eliminate them if necessary. Nothing is more valuable than God‚Äôs kingdom.

The illustration of the seed and the earth 26¬†Jesus said, ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs Kingdom is like a farmer spreading seed on the earth.

27¬†‚ÄúThe man sleeps and wakes night and day and the seed germinates and grows‚Äìeven though the man doesn‚Äôt fully understand how.

28¬†‚ÄúThe earth produces fruit by itself: first the blade, then the ear, then the mature grain in the ear.

29¬†‚ÄúBut when the fruit is ripe, immediately the farmer cuts the stalks down using his sickle‚Äìbecause the harvest has arrived.‚Äù

The illustration of the mustard seed 30¬†Jesus continued, ‚ÄúWhat is God‚Äôs Kingdom like? What word-picture illustrates it well?

31¬†‚ÄúGod‚Äôs Kingdom is like a single mustard seed.

‚ÄúEven though it‚Äôs the smallest seed 32¬†at planting time, it grows and matures into a larger plant than the other garden plants. It grows large branches and birds from high placesof the heavens nest in its shade.‚Äù

33¬†Jesus used many similar illustrations to explain the Word, up to the amount they could hear.

It‚Äôs God‚Äôs privilege to conceal things and the king‚Äôs privilege to discover them (reprise) 34¬†Jesus no longer spoke to the crowd except through illustrations!üîë When Jesus no longer speaks in a way we can understand, something is very wrong. But Mark tells us the way back: a) to spend private time with Jesus; b) to stay persistently where he is. But he explained everything privately to his students who stayed with him.

The illustration of the boat and the storm 35¬†That evening Jesus said, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go to the other side of the sea.‚Äù 36¬†Leaving the huge crowd, the students took Jesus with them and got into the boat; other small boats joined.

37¬†A large wind-storm rose and the waves broke into the boat‚Äìso badly that the boat was nearly swamped!

38¬†Jesus was in the back of the boat, asleep on a cushion!

His students woke him up demanding, ‚ÄúTeacher! Don‚Äôt you care that we are dying?‚Äù

39¬†Jesus woke up and corrected the wind! He commanded the sea, ‚ÄúSilence! Be still!‚Äù The wind suddenly stopped and a great calm came over the sea!

40¬†Jesus asked the students, ‚ÄúWhy are you so afraid? Why don‚Äôt you have expectant trustfaith instead?‚Äù

41¬†They were deeply frightened and asked each other, ‚ÄúWho is this? Even the wind and the sea obey him!‚Äù

An invitation; a new beginning 1¬†The beginningüîë Mark‚Äôs book is the only one in that claims to start at the beginning./jesuss-arrival of the Good News of Jesus: the one who God chose, the one with God‚Äôs approval, and the one with God‚Äôs own authority.Lit: Christ / Messiah / Anointed One The one who is the Son of God.

Prepare yourself‚Äìto be introduced to Jesus 2¬†The prophets wrote‚Äìspeaking for God himself:

Look! I am sending my messenger ahead of you; he will prepare your road ahead of time:Mal 3:1

3¬†the voice of one shouting in the desert, ‚ÄúMake The Ruler‚ÄôsWho is the Ruler? What is the nature of this Ruler‚Äôs authority? road ready! Make his paths straight!‚ÄùIsa 40:3

4¬†John came, ceremonially immersing people (under water)baptizing, which means ‚Äúimmersing‚Äù in the desert and declaring peoples‚Äô need to immerse their affectionsa baptism in God‚Äôs straight paths instead of their own.of repentance John said that when they fulfilled this condition they would be forgiven for preferring selfish pleasureJas 4:1-3 (and the hurt that this causes) instead.for their sins

5¬†All the country of Judea and all those of Jerusalem left their homes and towns to find John; he ceremonially immersedbaptized them in the Jordan river as they turned to God‚Äôs way. They took responsibility for and began changingrepented the selfish paths they had chosen‚Äìpaths that ultimately hurt themselves, God, and others as a consequence of their preference for selfish pleasure.of their sins

6¬†John was clothed with camel‚Äôs hair, wore a leather belt around his waist, and ate locusts and wild honey for food.

7¬†John foretold:

A man will come after me who is more powerful than I am; out of deep respect it would not even be appropriate for me to stoop down and untie his sandal straps!‚ÄùI am not worthy to stoop down and‚Ä¶

8¬†I ceremonially immersedbaptized you in water, but he will immersebaptize you in the Holy Spirit‚Äìthe One Spirit whose purposeTo be holy is to be uniquely set apart for a special purpose. is to help you enter and follow God‚Äôs Way.

Jesus chooses God‚Äôs road for his life 9¬†In those days Jesus came from Nazareth (a town in Galilee) and John ceremonially immersedbaptized him in the Jordan river.Jesus (the ‚Äògreater one‚Äô) was ceremonially immersed by John (the ‚Äòlesser one‚Äô), indicating Jesus‚Äôs choice to follow God‚Äôs paths‚Äìno matter the personal cost.Mrk 10:38-40 10¬†Immediately when Jesus broke the water‚Äôs surface, he saw the heavens splitting apart and the Holy Spirit descending on him in the form of a dove. 11¬†A voice came out of the sky, ‚ÄúYou are my dearly-loved Son; I am delighted with you!‚Äù

12¬†Immediately the Holy Spirit drove Jesus away from there into the desert. 13¬†He stayed in the desert forty days, tempted by Satan;Lit: Accuser or plaintiff; the chief evil spirit or demon (as opposed to the Holy Spirit, who is the Spirit of God.) he was with the wild animals and the angelsLit: God‚Äôs messengers were helping him.

There is a good kingdom and a perfect king 14¬†Now after John was arrested, Jesus entered Galilee declaring the Good News of God‚Äôs Kingdom. Jesus is the kingly Ruler who John and the prophets foretold.

15¬†‚ÄúThe time is fulfilled! God‚Äôs Kingdom is here!‚Äù Jesus said.

‚ÄúChange your citizenship from your own kingdom to God‚Äôs, surrender to his leadership, and align your own preferences to his values.repent And believe in the Good News!‚Äù

A king has authority over his followers‚Äô lives 16¬†Passing along the sea of Galilee, Jesus saw Simon and Andrew (Simon‚Äôs brother) casting a net into the sea; they worked as fishermen. 17¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúFollow me, and I will make you into fishers for men.‚Äù 18¬†Immediately they left their nets and followed him. 19¬†Going on a little further from there, Jesus saw James, Zebedee‚Äôs son, and John his brother. (James and John were in their boat repairing their nets.) 20¬†Immediately Jesus called to James and John and they left their father, Zebedee, in the boat with his hired helpers and followed Jesus!

The king has authority to speak God‚Äôs word 21¬†They entered Capernaum, and when the Sabbath day came Jesus immediately entered the synagogue and taught. 22¬†Everyone was amazed at his teaching because Jesus taught them like a person with authority, and not like the religious leaders who were scribes.

The king has authority over demons 23¬†Immediately in their synagogue a man with a an evil spiritDemons were also known as evil or unclean spirits; see also verse 32 shouted, 24¬†‚ÄúHa! What do we have to do with you Jesus, you Nazarene? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are: the Holye.g.: Chosen; separated to a purpose of perfect good-will One of God!‚Äù

25¬†Jesus strongly corrected the evil spirit! ‚ÄúBe quiet! Come out of him!‚Äù Jesus commanded the spirit.

26¬†The unclean spirit convulsed the man and shrieked loudly! Then the evil spirit came out of him.

27¬†Everyone was amazed! They all wondered about this! They all discussed the news!

‚ÄúWhat is this? A new teaching? Jesus even has authority to command the evil spirits! And they obey him!‚Äù they said.

28¬†The news about Jesus immediately spread everywhere in the region known as ‚ÄúGalilee‚Äù and its surrounding area.

The king has authority over sickness 29¬†Immediately, (when they had left the synagogue) they entered Simon and Andrew‚Äôs house with James and John. 30¬†Now Simon‚Äôs wife‚Äôs mother lay sick with a fever and they told Jesus about her immediately.

31¬†He came, took her by the hand, and raised her up. The fever immediately left her and she served them!

32¬†In the evening after the sun had set people who knew about Jesus brought all who were sick and those who were possessed by demons to him. 33¬†All the city was gathered together at the door!

34¬†Jesus healed many who were sick with various diseases and cast out many demons. He didn‚Äôt allow the demons to speak, because they knew him.

Jesus chooses God‚Äôs way over human expectations‚Ä¶Mark now begins a series of stories that compare and contrast expectant trust in God with things that get in the way of expectant trust. 35¬†Early in the morning while it was still dark Jesus got up, went out, left Capernaum for a deserted place, and prayed there.

36¬†Simon and those who were with him searched for Jesus. 37¬†When they found him they said, ‚ÄúEveryone is looking for you!‚Äù

38¬†Jesus replied, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go somewhere else‚Äîinto the next towns‚Äîso I can speak there too. This is why I came.‚Äù

39¬†So Jesus visited synagogues throughout the region of Galilee, speaking and casting out demons.

‚Ä¶But a sick man doesn‚Äôt 40¬†A man with the highly contagious, incurable, fatal skin disease known asThese characteristics of leprosy were common knowledge in Mark‚Äôs time leprosy found Jesus in order to beg. Lowering himself to his knees in front of Jesus he said, ‚ÄúIf you want to, you can make me clean!‚Äù

41¬†With deep compassion, Jesus stretched out his hand, touched the LeperLepers were a lower class in society, not just people with the disease known as leprosy in reply and said, ‚ÄúI want to! Be cleansed.‚Äù

42¬†When Jesus said this, immediately the leprosy left the man‚Äìhe was made clean; he was completely healed!

43¬†Jesus strictly warned the man (immediately sending him on his way), 44¬†‚ÄúBe careful that you don‚Äôt speak a word about this to anybody. Instead, go show yourself to the priest and offer the sacrifices Moses commanded for your cleansing. (This will be a witness to the priests.)‚Äù

45¬†However, when the man left he told everybody and spread the news all over!

As a result, Jesus couldn‚Äôt enter cities any more but instead stayed outside the cities in the desert.

People still came to Jesus from all around.

item.content:encoded:
The illustration of two armies 1¬†They came to the other side of the sea, into the country of the Gadarenes.

2¬†When Jesus left the boat, immediately a man with an evil spiritLit: unclean spirit; also known as a demon ran from the tombs to meet him. 3¬†This man lived in the tombs.or: the burial caves

Nobody could tie or restrain him any more‚Äìnot even using chains! 4¬†The people around frequently bound him using shackles and chains, but he tore the chains apart and broke the shackles in pieces. Nobody had the strength to subdue him!

5¬†All night, all day he wandered among the burial caves and the mountains; he was constantly shrieking and cutting himself with sharp stones.

6¬†When he saw Jesus from far away, he ran and bowed low to him. 7¬†He roared, ‚ÄúWhat do I have to do with you‚ÄìJesus, you Son of the Most High God? I command you by God, don‚Äôt torture me!‚Äù

8¬†(Jesus had already said, ‚ÄúCome out of the man, you evilLit: unclean spirit!‚Äú)

9¬†Jesus asked him, ‚ÄúWhat is your name?‚Äù

He said to Jesus, ‚ÄúMy name is Legion,A legion was between 4000 and 6000 Roman soldiers. The demons didn‚Äôt just emphasize that there were a lot of them, but used language indicating that they saw themselves as warriors prepared to fight for their kingdom and their king. for we are many‚Äù 10¬†and begged Jesus over and over not to send them away‚Äìout of the country.

11¬†Now a large herd of pigs was feeding there on the side of the hill. 12¬†And the demons begged Jesus, ‚ÄúSend us into the pigs! Allow us to enter them!‚Äù

13¬†Jesus gave them permission.

Then the evilLit: unclean spirits came out of the man, entered the pigs, and the herd of about two thousand pigs rushed down the steep hillside into the sea where they drowned!üîë Satan is a liar. He promises pleasure but those who dedicate their lives to his cause ultimately find destruction. Jesus is more powerful than Satan and his legions. Renounce Satan‚Äôs kingdom, love of violence, and every form of occult practice, dedicate your life to God‚Äôs perfect kingdom, and expectantly trust Jesus.

14¬†Those who fed the pigs ran away in fear, spreading the news in the city and in the country! And the people came to see what had happened.

The crowd did not understand who Jesus is‚Ä¶ 15¬†The people came to Jesus, saw the man who had been possessed by demons sitting, clothed, and in his right mind‚Äìyes even this man who had the legion of evil spirits‚Äìand they were afraid.

16¬†The eyewitnesses explained to the crowd what happened to the man who had been demon-possessed and also to the pigs!

17¬†Then the crowd begged Jesus to leave their region!

‚Ä¶But the man who was delivered from the devils did 18¬†As Jesus entered the boat to leave, the man who had been possessed by demons fervently begged to join him so he could be with him.

19¬†Jesus wouldn‚Äôt allow this but replied, ‚ÄúGo to your family and friends; tell them everything the Ruler has done for you and how he had mercy on you!‚Äù

20¬†So the man began spreading the news all around the ten towns in the region,Lit. the ‚Äúregion-of-ten-cities‚Äù that was located east of the Jordan River explaining how Jesus had done so much for him!

Everyone was amazed.

Two illustrations about touch‚Ä¶ 21¬†When Jesus returned to the other side in a boat, a huge crowd joined him by the sea. 22¬†And a synagogue ruler named Jairus arrived.

When Jairus saw Jesus he fell at Jesus‚Äôs feet!

‚Ä¶imploring Jesus to touch others so they may be healed 23¬†Over and over Jairus begged, ‚ÄúMy little daughter is about to die! Please come! Please reach out and touch her with your hands so she can be wholly well, so she can live!‚ÄùLit: so she can be wholly well and live

24¬†Jesus went with Jairus. A very large crowd followed‚Äìpressing in on Jesus from every side.

‚Ä¶having the persistence to touch Jesus ourselves 25¬†A particular woman in the crowd had blood oozing from her body for twelve years. 26¬†Having suffered through many doctors‚Äô attempts to heal her she had spent all her money and hadn‚Äôt gotten any better. Instead her symptoms grew worse.

27¬†But she heard about Jesus.

And she worked her way through the crowd behind Jesus and touched his clothes. 28¬†She had said, ‚ÄúIf I just touch his clothes, I will be well again!‚Äù

29¬†Immediately her flow of blood dried up and she realized that she had been healed from her sickness!

30¬†And immediately Jesus knew that mighty power had gone out from him so he turned around in the jostling crowd and asked, ‚ÄúWho touched my clothes?‚Äù

31¬†His students asked, ‚ÄúYou see this large crowd pressing against you? And you say, ‚ÄòWho touched me?‚Äô‚Äù

32¬†Jesus looked around him, trying to see the woman who had done this.

33¬†The woman, realizing what had happened to her, came to Jesus. Afraid and shaking, she fell down in front of him and told him the whole truth.

34¬†Jesus replied, ‚ÄúDaughter, your expectant trustfaith has made you well. Go in peace, be wholly well; your sickness that has tortured your body and heartMore literally: scourge; e.g.: the whip used by Roman soldiers to punish, torture, and intimidate is gone.‚Äù

‚Ä¶persisting with Jesus until people are ‚Äúraised from the dead‚Äù 35¬†While Jesus was still speaking, messengers from the synagogue ruler‚Äôs home arrived with news. ‚ÄúYour daughter is dead. Why bother the Teacher any more?‚Äù they said.

36¬†But Jesus, when he heard the news, immediately assured the synagogue ruler, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be afraid, only believe!‚Äù 37¬†And Jesus asked that only Peter, James, and John the brother of James join him.

38¬†When they arrived at the synagogue ruler‚Äôs house Jesus saw a chaotic scene: people weeping and sobbing loudly!

39¬†Jesus entered the house.

‚ÄúWhy are you making a chaotic scene and weeping‚Äìthe child isn‚Äôt dead, but is asleep?‚Äù Jesus asked.

40¬†They mocked Jesus.

But after Jesus put them out of the house, he invited the girl‚Äôs father, mother, and those who were with him to join him; together they entered the place the child was lying. 41¬†Taking the child by her hand Jesus said, ‚ÄúTalitha cumi!‚Äù (This translates to, ‚ÄúLittle girl, I tell you, get up!‚Äú)

42¬†Immediately the girl got up and walked; she was twelve years old. And those present were deeply astonished and amazed!

43¬†Jesus strictly ordered those present not to tell a single person what had happened and instructed them to give the girl something to eat.

Jesus couldn‚Äôt do miracles when there wasn‚Äôt expectant trust in him 1¬†Jesus continued from Jairus‚Äôs home and entered his hometown; his disciples went with him.

2¬†On the Sabbath day, Jesus started teaching in the synagogue and many people who heard him were surprised and amazed.struck with astonishment

‚ÄúWhere did this man get these ideas? What is this wisdom that is being given to him so that these miracles are being done through his hands? 3¬†Isn‚Äôt this the carpenter, Mary‚Äôs son, the brother of James, Joses, Judah, and Simon? Aren‚Äôt his sisters living here too?‚Äù they said.

So they were offendedor scandalized at him.

4¬†Jesus replied, ‚ÄúA prophet isn‚Äôt dishonored‚Äìexcept in his own country, in his hometown, and among his own relatives.‚Äù

5¬†Jesus wasn‚Äôt able to do miracles there, except to lay his hands on a few sick people and heal them!

6¬†He was amazed because of their lack of expectant trustfaithlessness; or traditionally: unbelief so he traveled around the towns in the area and spent his time teaching.

‚Ä¶but the twelve obeyed Jesus in expectant trust 7¬†Jesus called the twelve, and began sending them out two by two.

He gave them authority over the demons.unclean spirits 8¬†He told them not to take anything for their journey except for a walking stick. He didn‚Äôt allow them to take food, a wallet, or money. He allowed them to wear sandals but not to bring extra clothes.

10¬†Jesus said to them,

Wherever someone from a city offers their home as a place to stay, stay there until you leave their city.

11¬†Whenever a city‚Äôs people will not receive you into one of their homes or hear your message, leave! And shake off the dust that is under your feet for a legal witness against what they did!

[I say with certainty: it will be more tolerable for Sodom and GomorrahGen 19 on the day everyone‚Äôs acts and motives are judgedOr: in the day of judgement than for that city!] The earliest and best copies of Mark‚Äôs manuscript do not contain this sentence but it does appear in Matthew‚Äôs telling of this story. Mat 10:1-15

‚Ä¶and many people received the message with expectant trust 12¬†They went out and warned people to turn away from making selfish pleasure their primary life‚Äôs goal. 13¬†They cast out many demons; they anointed many with oil who were sick and healed them.

Herod was blind about Jesus: 14¬†King HerodHerod was the corrupt puppet king the Romans had placed over Israel. heard this, for his name had become known, and he said, ‚ÄúJohn the Baptist has risen from the dead, and therefore these powers are at work in him.‚Äù 15¬†But others said, ‚ÄúHe is Elijah.‚Äù Others said, ‚ÄúHe is a prophet, or like one of the prophets.‚Äù

16¬†But Herod, when he heard this, said, ‚ÄúThis is John, whom I beheaded. He has risen from the dead.‚Äù

‚Ä¶because his personal pleasure was supreme 17¬†For Herod himself had sent out and arrested John and bound him in prison for the sake of Herodias, his brother Philip‚Äôs wife, for he had married her. 18¬†For John had said to Herod, ‚ÄúIt is against God‚Äôs law for you to have your brother‚Äôs wife.‚Äù

19¬†Herodias set herself against him and desired to kill him, but she couldn‚Äôt, 20¬†for Herod feared John, knowing that he was a righteous and holy man, and kept him safe. When he heard him, he did many things, and he heard him gladly. Herod likes to hear about God, but refuses the seed John offers. It‚Äôs not enough to enjoy hearing about God; we need to apply and practice what we learn.

‚Ä¶because he placed political power over expectant trust 21¬†Then a convenient day came when Herod on his birthday made a supper for his nobles, the high officers, and the chief men of Galilee.

22¬†When the daughter of Herodias (also named Herodias) came in and danced, she pleased Herod and those sitting with him. The king said to the young lady, ‚ÄúAsk me whatever you want, and I will give it to you.‚Äù 23¬†He swore to her, ‚ÄúWhatever you ask of me, I will give you, up to half of my kingdom.‚Äù

24¬†She went out and said to her mother, ‚ÄúWhat shall I ask?‚Äù Her mother replied, ‚ÄúThe head of John the Baptist.‚Äù 25¬†Immediately Herodius hurried to the king and requested, ‚ÄúI want you to give me right now the head of John the Baptist on a platter.‚Äù

26¬†The king was exceedingly sorry, but for the sake of his oaths and of his dinner guests, he didn‚Äôt want to refuse her.

‚Ä¶until he killed the messenger sent to help him see 27¬†Immediately the king sent a soldier from his bodyguard to the prison with the command to bring back John‚Äôs head. The soldier went to the prison and beheaded John, 28¬† brought his head on a platter, and gave it to the young lady; and the young lady gave it to her mother.

29¬†When John‚Äôs students heard the news they came, claimed his body, and buried it in a tomb.

The illustration of plentiful provision from emptiness 30¬†The twelve ambassadorsTraditionally ‚Äòapostles‚Äô but the word has fallen out of everyday spoken English.This is the only place Mark uses ‚Äúambassador‚Äù/‚Äúdelegate‚Äù instead of ‚Äústudent‚Äù to refer to the twelve. returned to Jesus and told him all that they had done and taught.

31¬†Jesus said, ‚ÄúCome with me; let‚Äôs go to an empty wilderness and rest awhile. (There were many people who were coming and going and there wasn‚Äôt even enough spare time to eat!)

32¬†So Jesus and his students left in the boat, heading to an empty wilderness by themselves.

33¬†But the crowd saw them getting farther and farther away! And many people from all the towns (along the way) recognized Jesus, ran to the empty wilderness place on foot, and arrived first!

34¬†When Jesus landed, he saw a very large crowd.

And Jesus‚Äôs heart broke for them because they were like sheep who were wandering without a shepherd‚Äìin danger for their lives. So Jesus began teaching them many things.Or maybe from the students‚Äô perspective: ‚Äòbegan a very very long sermon‚Äô.

35¬†When the day was nearly over, Jesus‚Äôs students came to him and said, ‚ÄúThis place is a wilderness and the day is fading!more literally: ‚Äúthe day is spent‚Äù 36¬†Send these people away! Then they can go into the surrounding country, into the tiny villages, and buy themselves bread because they have nothing to eat!‚Äù

37¬†But Jesus answered his students, ‚ÄúYou give them something to eat!‚Äù

They asked Jesus, ‚ÄúShould we go into the tiny villagesThe place where the disciples would go, ‚Äúinto the tiny villages,‚Äù is added here from the context and buy two hundred denarii‚Äîtwo hundred days‚Äô wages‚Äîworth of bread and give them something to eat?‚Äù

38¬†Jesus replied, ‚ÄúHow many loaves do you have? Go see.‚Äù

When they found out they said, ‚ÄúFive loaves, and two fish!‚Äù

39¬†Jesus told everyone to sit down in groups on the green grass 40¬†and they sat down in groups of hundreds and fifties.

The Bread is broken first, then the Fish are broken too 41¬†Jesus took the five loavesüîë Looking forward, Jesus broke bread during his last supper with his students.Mrk 14:22 and the two fish.üîë Looking backward, Jesus promised to teach his students to ‚Äúfish‚Äù for people when he invited them to join him.Mrk 1:17A theme Mark begins developing is, ‚ÄúWhat did it mean for Jesus to be broken? For us to be broken too?‚Äù

Looking up to heaven, he blessed and broke the loaves, which he gave to his disciples to set before them. He also divided the two fish among them all.

42¬†Everyone ate until they were full; 43¬†afterward the students gathered twelve baskets full of bread and fish!

44¬†Approximately five thousand men were in the crowd (in addition to women and children)!

People persistently call to Jesus; he is willing and able to meet each at their point of need 45¬†Immediately Jesus made his disciples enter the boat and go ahead of him to the other side, to Bethsaida, while he personally sent the huge crowd away. 46¬†And after he had dismissed everyone, he climbed up the mountain to pray.

47¬†When evening arrive, the boat was in the middle of the sea and Jesus was alone on the land.

48¬†Seeing his students deeply frustrated because they were rowing against the wind, a little before dawnLit: ‚Äòabout the fourth watch of the night‚Äô Jesus came to them‚Äìwalking on the sea. He would have passed by them, 49¬†but when they saw Jesus walking on the sea they thought he was a ghost and cried out! 50¬†They all saw him; all of them were afraid!

But Jesus immediately called out to them, ‚ÄúCheer up! I‚Äôm here! Don‚Äôt be afraid.‚Äù 51¬†He got into the boat with them and the wind suddenly stopped.

And the students were very amazed and astonished 52¬†because they hadn‚Äôt understood about the loaves; instead their hearts were hard.

53¬†When they had crossed over, they landed at GennesaretThis is the same region where Jesus cast out the ‚ÄòLegion‚Äô of demons earlier. and moored to the shore. Mrk 5

54¬†They exited the boat and immediately the people recognized him! 55¬†They ran all over the region and began to bring those who were sick on their mats to the locations where they heard Jesus was present.

56¬†Wherever Jesus entered‚Äîinto villages, into cities, or into the country‚Äîthey laid the sick in the marketplaces and begged him to just let them touch the fringe of his garment.

And everyone who touched Jesus was made well. Ôªø

item.description: 1¬†Then the Pharisees and some of the scribes gathered together to him, having come from Jerusalem. 2¬†Now when they saw some of his disciples eating bread with defiled‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†Then the Pharisees and some of the scribes gathered together to him, having come from Jerusalem. 2¬†Now when they saw some of his disciples eating bread with defiled, that is unwashed, hands, they found fault. 3¬†(For the Pharisees and all the Jews don‚Äôt eat unless they wash their hands and forearms, holding to the tradition of the elders. 4¬†They don‚Äôt eat when they come from the marketplace unless they bathe themselves, and there are many other things which they have received to hold to: washings of cups, pitchers, bronze vessels, and couches.) 5¬†The Pharisees and the scribes asked him, ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt your disciples walk according to the tradition of the elders, but eat their bread with unwashed hands?‚Äù 6¬†He answered them, ‚ÄúWell did Isaiah prophesy of you hypocrites, as it is written, ‚ÄòThis people honors me with their lips, but their heart is far from me. 7¬†They worship me in vain, teaching the commandments of men as if they were God‚Äôs principles and instructions.‚Äô 8¬†‚ÄúFor you set aside the commandment of God, and hold tightly to the tradition of men‚Äîthe washing of pitchers and cups, and you do many other such things.‚Äù 9¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúFull well do you reject the commandment of God, that you may keep your tradition. 10¬†For Moses said, ‚ÄòHonor your father and your mother;‚Äô and, ‚ÄòHe who speaks evil of father or mother, let him be put to death.‚Äô 11¬†But you say, ‚ÄòIf a man tells his father or his mother, ‚ÄúWhatever profit you might have received from me is Corban,‚Äù‚Äô‚Äù (that is, he vowed to ‚Äúgive to God‚Äù what he would have given to them), 12¬†‚Äúthen you no longer allow him to do anything for his father or his mother, 13¬†making void the word of God by your tradition which you have handed down. You do many things like this.‚Äù 14¬†He called all the great crowd to himself and said to them, ‚ÄúHear me, all of you, and understand. 15¬†There is nothing from outside of the man that going into him can defile him; but the things which proceed out of the man are those that defile the man. 16¬†If anyone has ears to hear, let him carefully take this to heart!‚Äù 17¬†When he had entered into a house away from the great crowd, his disciples asked him about the object lesson. 18¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúAre you also without understanding? Don‚Äôt you perceive that whatever goes into the man from outside can‚Äôt defile him, 19¬†because it doesn‚Äôt go into his heart, but into his stomach, then into the latrine, making all foods clean?‚Äù 20¬†He said, ‚Äúwhat proceeds out of the man, that defiles the man. 21¬†For from within, out of the hearts of men, proceed evil thoughts, adulteries, sexual sins, murders, thefts, 22¬†greed, wickedness, deceit, lustful desires, an evil eye, defaming God, pride, and foolishness. 23¬†All these evil things come from within and defile the man.‚Äù 24¬†From there he got up and went away into the borders of Tyre and Sidon. He entered into a house and didn‚Äôt want anyone to know it, but he couldn‚Äôt escape notice. 25¬†For a woman whose little daughter had an unclean spirit, having heard of him, came and fell down at his feet. 26¬†Now the woman was a Greek gentile, a Syrian-Phoenician by race. She begged him that he would cast the demon out of her daughter. 27¬†But Jesus said to her, ‚ÄúLet the children be filled first, for it is not appropriate to take the children‚Äôs bread and throw it to the dogs.‚Äù 28¬†But she answered him, ‚ÄúYes, Lord. Yet even the dogs under the table eat the children‚Äôs crumbs.‚Äù 29¬†He said to her, ‚ÄúBecause of this answer, go your way. The demon has gone out of your daughter.‚Äù 30¬†She went away to her house, and found the child having been laid on the bed, with the demon gone out. 31¬†Again he left the borders of Tyre and Sidon, and came to the sea of Galilee through the middle of the region of Decapolis (that is, the ten-cities-east-of-Jordan). 32¬†They brought to him one who was deaf and had an impediment in his speech. They begged him to lay his hand on him. 33¬†He took him aside from the great crowd privately and put his fingers into his ears; and he spat and touched his tongue. 34¬†Looking up to heaven, he sighed, and said to him, ‚ÄúEphphatha!‚Äù that is, ‚ÄúBe opened!‚Äù 35¬†Immediately his ears were opened, and the impediment of his tongue was released, and he spoke clearly. 36¬†He commanded them that they should tell no one, but the more he commanded them, so much the more widely they proclaimed it. 37¬†They were beyond amazed, saying, ‚ÄúHe has done all things well. He makes even the deaf hear and the mute speak!‚Äù Ôªø

item.title: Mark 8
item.description: 1¬†In those days, when there was an even larger crowd‚Äîand they had nothing to eat. Jesus called his disciples to himself and said to them, 2¬†‚ÄúI have compassion on this‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†In those days, when there was an even larger crowd‚Äîand they had nothing to eat. Jesus called his disciples to himself and said to them, 2¬†‚ÄúI have compassion on this great crowd, because they have stayed with me now three days and have nothing to eat. 3¬†If I send them to their home without eating they will faint on the way, for some of them have come a long way.‚Äù 4¬†His disciples answered him, ‚ÄúFrom where could one satisfy these people with bread here in a deserted place?‚Äù 5¬†He asked them, ‚ÄúHow many loaves do you have?‚Äù They said, ‚ÄúSeven.‚Äù 6¬†He commanded the great crowd to sit down on the ground, and he took the seven loaves. Having given thanks, he broke them and gave them to his disciples to serve, and they served the crowd. 7¬†They also had a few small fish. Having blessed them, he said to serve these also. 8¬†Everyone ate until they were full and the disciples gathered seven baskets of broken pieces that were left over. 9¬†Those who had eaten were about four thousand. Then Jesus sent them away. 10¬†Immediately he entered into the boat with his disciples and came into the region of Dalmanutha. 11¬†The Pharisees came out and began to question him, requesting from him a sign from heaven to test him. 12¬†He sighed deeply in his spirit and said, ‚ÄúWhy does this generation ask for a sign? With certainty I tell you, no sign will be given to this generation.‚Äù 13¬†He left them, and again entering into the boat, left for the other side. 14¬†They forgot to take bread; and they didn‚Äôt have more than one loaf in the boat with them. 15¬†He warned them, saying, ‚ÄúPay careful attention: beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the yeast of Herod.‚Äù 16¬†They reasoned with one another, saying, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs because we have no bread.‚Äù 17¬†Jesus, perceiving it, said to them, ‚ÄúWhy do you reason that it‚Äôs because you have no bread? Don‚Äôt you perceive yet or understand? Is your heart still hardened? 18¬†Having eyes, don‚Äôt you see? Having ears, don‚Äôt you hear? Don‚Äôt you remember? 19¬†When I broke the five loaves among the five thousand, how many baskets full of broken pieces did you take up?‚Äù They told him, ‚ÄúTwelve.‚Äù 20¬†‚ÄúWhen the seven loaves fed the four thousand, how many baskets full of broken pieces did you take up?‚Äù They told him, ‚ÄúSeven.‚Äù 21¬†He asked them, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you understand yet?‚Äù 22¬†He came to Bethsaida. They brought a blind man to him and begged him to touch him. 23¬†He took hold of the blind man by the hand, and brought him out of the village. When he had spat on his eyes, and laid his hands on him, he asked him if he saw anything. 24¬†He looked up, and said, ‚ÄúI see men, but I see them like walking trees.‚Äù 25¬†Then again he laid his hands on his eyes. He looked intently, and was restored, and saw everyone clearly. 26¬†He sent him away to his house, saying, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt enter into the village, nor tell anyone in the village.‚Äù 27¬†Jesus went out, with his disciples, into the villages of Caesarea Philippi. On the way he asked his disciples, ‚ÄúWho do men say that I am?‚Äù 28¬†They told him, ‚ÄúJohn the Baptist, and others say Elijah, but others, one of the prophets.‚Äù 29¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúBut who do you say that I am?‚Äù Peter answered, ‚ÄúYou are the Messiah.‚Äù 30¬†He commanded them that they should tell no one about him. 31¬†He began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders, the chief priests, and the scribes, and be killed, and after three days rise again. 32¬†He spoke to them openly. Peter took him and began to reprimand him. 33¬†But he, turning around and seeing his disciples, reprimanded Peter, and said, ‚ÄúGet behind me, Satan! For you have in mind not the things of God, but the things of men.‚Äù 34¬†He called the great crowd to himself with his disciples and said to them, ‚ÄúWhoever wants to come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me. 35¬†For whoever wants to save his life will lose it; and whoever will lose his life for my sake and the sake of the Good News will save it. 36¬†For what does it profit a man to gain the whole world and forfeit his life? 37¬†For what will a man give in exchange for his life? 38¬†For whoever will be ashamed of me and of my words in this adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of Man also will be ashamed of him when he comes in his Father‚Äôs glory with the holy angels.‚Äù Ôªø

item.title: Mark 10
item.description: 1¬†He got up from there and came into the borders of Judea and beyond the Jordan. Large crowds came together to him again. And again‚Äîas he usually did‚Äîhe taught them. 2¬†‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†He got up from there and came into the borders of Judea and beyond the Jordan. Large crowds came together to him again. And again‚Äîas he usually did‚Äîhe taught them. 2¬†Pharisees came to him testing him, and asked him, ‚ÄúIs it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?‚Äù 3¬†He answered, ‚ÄúWhat did Moses command you?‚Äù 4¬†They said, ‚ÄúMoses allowed a certificate of divorce to be written, and to divorce her.‚Äù 5¬†But Jesus said to them, ‚ÄúFor your hardness of heart, he wrote you this commandment. 6¬†But from the beginning of the creation, God made them male and female. 7¬†For this cause a man will leave his father and mother, and will join to his wife, 8¬†and the two will become one flesh, so that they are no longer two, but one flesh. 9¬†What therefore God has joined together, let no man separate.‚Äù 10¬†In the house, his disciples asked him again about the same matter. 11¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúWhoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery against her. 12¬†If a woman herself divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery.‚Äù 13¬†They were bringing to him little children, that he should touch them, but the disciples reprimanded those who were bringing them. 14¬†But when Jesus saw it, indignation rose in his heart and he said to his disciples, ‚ÄúAllow the little children to come to me! Don‚Äôt forbid them, for God‚Äôs Kingdom belongs to such as these. 15¬†I tell you with complete certainty, whoever will not receive God‚Äôs Kingdom like a little child, he will in no way enter into it.‚Äù 16¬†He took them in his arms and blessed them, laying his hands on them. 17¬†As he was starting on the way to Jerusalem, a man ran to him, knelt before him, and asked him, ‚ÄúGood Teacher, what shall I do that I may inherit eternal life?‚Äù 18¬†Jesus said to him, ‚ÄúWhy do you call me good? No one is good except one‚ÄîGod. 19¬†You know the commandments: ‚ÄòDo not murder,‚Äô ‚ÄòDo not commit adultery,‚Äô ‚ÄòDo not steal,‚Äô ‚ÄòDo not give false testimony,‚Äô ‚ÄòDo not cheat anyone,‚Äô ‚ÄòHonor your father and mother.‚Äô‚Äù 20¬†He said to him, ‚ÄúTeacher, I have observed all these things from my youth.‚Äù 21¬†Jesus looking at him loved him, and said to him, ‚ÄúOne thing you lack. Go, sell whatever you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me, taking up the cross.‚Äù 22¬†But his face fell at that saying, and he went away sorrowful, for he was one who had great possessions. 23¬†Jesus looked around and said to his disciples, ‚ÄúHow difficult it is for those who have riches to enter into God‚Äôs Kingdom!‚Äù 24¬†The disciples were amazed at his words. But Jesus answered again, ‚ÄúChildren, how hard it is for those who trust in riches to enter into God‚Äôs Kingdom! 25¬†It is easier for a camel to go through a needle‚Äôs eye than for a rich man to enter into God‚Äôs Kingdom.‚Äù 26¬†They were exceedingly amazed, saying to him, ‚ÄúThen who can be saved?‚Äù 27¬†Jesus, looking at them, said, ‚ÄúWith men it is impossible, but not with God, for all things are possible with God.‚Äù 28¬†Peter began to tell him, ‚ÄúLook! we have left all and have followed you.‚Äù 29¬†Jesus said, ‚ÄúWith certainty I tell you, there is no one who has left house, or brothers, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or land, for my sake, and for the sake of the Good News, 30¬†but he will receive one hundred times more now in this time: houses, brothers, sisters, mothers, children, and land, with persecutions; and in the age to come eternal life. 31¬†But many who are first will be last, and the last first.‚Äù 32¬†They were on the way, going up to Jerusalem; and Jesus was going in front of them, and the disciples were amazed; and those who followed were afraid. He again took the twelve aside and began to tell them the things that were going to happen to him. 33¬†‚ÄúLook! we are going up to Jerusalem. The Son of Man will be delivered to the chief priests and the scribes. They will condemn him to death, and will deliver him to the Gentiles. 34¬†They will mock him, spit on him, scourge him, and kill him. On the third day he will rise again.‚Äù 35¬†James and John, the sons of Zebedee, approached him, saying, ‚ÄúTeacher, we want you to do for us whatever we will ask.‚Äù 36¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúWhat do you want me to do for you?‚Äù 37¬†They said to him, ‚ÄúGrant to us that we may sit, one at your right hand and one at your left hand, in your glory.‚Äù 38¬†But Jesus said to them, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I drink, and to be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with?‚Äù 39¬†They said to him, ‚ÄúWe are able.‚Äù Jesus said to them, ‚ÄúYou shall indeed drink the cup that I drink, and you shall be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with; 40¬†but to sit at my right hand and at my left hand is not mine to give, but for whom it has been prepared.‚Äù 41¬†When the ten heard it, they began to be indignant towards James and John. 42¬†Jesus summoned them and said to them, ‚ÄúYou know that they who are recognized as rulers over the nations lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them. 43¬†But it shall not be so among you, but whoever wants to become great among you shall be your servant. 44¬†Whoever of you wants to become first among you shall offer himself as slave of all. 45¬†For the Son of Man also came not to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.‚Äù 46¬†They came to Jericho. As he went out from Jericho with his disciples and a great great crowd, a blind beggar named Bartimaeus (son of Timaeus), was sitting by the road. 47¬†When he heard that it was Jesus the Nazarene, he began to cry out and say, ‚ÄúJesus, you son of David, have mercy on me!‚Äù 48¬†Many reprimanded him, that he should be quiet, but he cried out much more, ‚ÄúYou son of David, have mercy on me!‚Äù 49¬†Jesus stood still and said, ‚ÄúCall him.‚Äù They called the blind man, saying to him, ‚ÄúCheer up! Get up. He is calling you!‚Äù 50¬†He, casting away his cloak, sprang up, and came to Jesus. 51¬†Jesus asked him, ‚ÄúWhat do you want me to do for you?‚Äù The blind man said to him, ‚ÄúRabboni, that I may see again.‚Äù 52¬†Jesus said to him, ‚ÄúGo your way. Your expectant trustfaith has made you well.‚Äù Immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus on the way. Ôªø
