item.title: Mark 9
item.description: 1¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúWith certainty I tell you, there are some standing here who will in no way taste death until they see God‚Äôs Kingdom come with power.‚Äù 2¬†After six‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúWith certainty I tell you, there are some standing here who will in no way taste death until they see God‚Äôs Kingdom come with power.‚Äù 2¬†After six days Jesus took with him Peter, James, and John, and brought them up onto a high mountain privately by themselves, and he was changed into another form in front of them. 3¬†His clothing became glistening, amazingly pure white, like snow, such as no launderer on earth can whiten them. 4¬†Elijah and Moses appeared to them, and they were talking with Jesus. 5¬†Peter answered Jesus, ‚ÄúRabbi, it is good for us to be here. Let‚Äôs make three tents: one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.‚Äù 6¬†For he didn‚Äôt know what to say, for they were very afraid. 7¬†A cloud came, overshadowing them, and a voice came out of the cloud, ‚ÄúThis is my beloved Son. Listen to him.‚Äù 8¬†Suddenly looking around, they saw no one with them any more, except Jesus only. 9¬†As they were coming down from the mountain, he commanded them that they should tell no one the things they had seen, until after the Son of Man had risen from the dead. 10¬†They kept this saying to themselves, questioning what the ‚Äúrising from the dead‚Äù meant. 11¬†They asked him, saying, ‚ÄúWhy do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?‚Äù 12¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúYes! Elijah comes first, and restores all things. (Yet why do the scriptures say regarding the Son of Man, that he should suffer many things and be treated with utter contempt?) 13¬†But I tell you that Elijah has come, and they have also done to him whatever they wanted to, even as it is written about him.‚Äù 14¬†Coming to the disciples, he saw a great great crowd around them, and scribes questioning them. 15¬†Immediately all the great crowd, when they saw him, were greatly amazed, and running to him, greeted him. 16¬†He asked the scribes, ‚ÄúWhat are you asking them?‚Äù 17¬†One of the people answered, ‚ÄúTeacher, I brought my son, who has a mute spirit; 18¬†and wherever it seizes him, it throws him down; and he foams at the mouth, grinds his teeth, and becomes rigid. I asked your disciples to cast it out, and they weren‚Äôt able.‚Äù 19¬†He answered him, ‚ÄúUnbelieving generation, how long shall I be with you? How long shall I bear with you? Bring him to me.‚Äù 20¬†They brought him to him, and when he saw him, immediately the spirit convulsed him and he fell on the ground, writhing and foaming at the mouth. 21¬†He asked his father, ‚ÄúHow long has it been since this has been happening to him?‚Äù He said, ‚ÄúFrom childhood. 22¬†Often it has cast him both into the fire and into the water to destroy him. But if you can do anything, have compassion on us and help us.‚Äù 23¬†Jesus said to him, ‚ÄúIf you can believe, all things are possible to him who believes.‚Äù 24¬†Immediately the father of the child cried out with tears, ‚ÄúI believe. Help my unbelief!‚Äù 25¬†When Jesus saw that people were running to join the crowd, he reprimanded the unclean spirit, saying to him, ‚ÄúYou mute and deaf spirit, I command you, come out of him, and never enter him again!‚Äù 26¬†After crying out and convulsing him greatly, it came out of him. The boy became like one dead, so much that most of them said, ‚ÄúHe is dead.‚Äù 27¬†But Jesus took him by the hand and raised him up; and he got up. 28¬†When he had come into the house, his disciples asked him privately, ‚ÄúWhy couldn‚Äôt we cast it out?‚Äù 29¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúThis kind cannot come out but by prayer and fasting.‚Äù 30¬†They went out from there and passed through Galilee. He didn‚Äôt want anyone to know it, 31¬†for he was teaching his disciples, and said to them, ‚ÄúThe Son of Man is being betrayed into the hands of his enemies, and they will kill him; and when he is killed, on the third day he will rise again.‚Äù 32¬†But they didn‚Äôt understand the saying, and were afraid to ask him. 33¬†He came to Capernaum, and when he was in the house he asked them, ‚ÄúWhat were you arguing among yourselves on the way?‚Äù 34¬†But they were silent, for they had disputed with one another on the way about who was the greatest. 35¬†He sat down and called the twelve; and he said to them, ‚ÄúIf any man wants to be first, he shall be last of all, and servant of all.‚Äù 36¬†He took a little child and set him in the middle of them. Taking him in his arms, he said to them, 37¬†‚ÄúWhoever receives one such little child in my name receives me; and whoever receives me, doesn‚Äôt receive me, but him who sent me.‚Äù 38¬†John said to him, ‚ÄúTeacher, we saw someone who doesn‚Äôt follow us casting out demons in your name; and we forbade him, because he doesn‚Äôt follow us.‚Äù 39¬†But Jesus said, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt forbid him, for there is no one who will do a mighty work in my name and be able to speak evil of me soon afterward. 40¬†For whoever is not against us is on our side. 41¬†For whoever will give you a cup of water to drink in my name because you belong to the Messiah, most certainly I tell you, he will in no way lose his reward. 42¬†‚ÄúWhoever will cause one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble, it would be better for him if he were thrown into the sea with a millstone hung around his neck. 43¬†If your hand causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter into life maimed, rather than having your two hands to go into Gehenna, into the unquenchable fire, 44¬†‚Äòwhere their worm doesn‚Äôt die, and the fire is not quenched.‚Äô 45¬†If your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter into life lame, rather than having your two feet to be cast into Gehenna, into the fire that will never be quenched‚Äî 46¬†‚Äòwhere their worm doesn‚Äôt die, and the fire is not quenched.‚Äô 47¬†If your eye causes you to stumble, throw it out. It is better for you to enter into God‚Äôs Kingdom with one eye, rather than having two eyes to be cast into the Gehenna of fire, 48¬†‚Äòwhere their worm doesn‚Äôt die, and the fire is not quenched.‚Äô 49¬†For everyone will be salted with fire, and every sacrifice will be seasoned with salt. 50¬†Salt is good, but if the salt has lost its flavor, how can a person add its character back? Have salt‚Äôs qualities in yourselves, and be at peace with one another.‚Äù Ôªø

item.title: Mark 11
item.description: 1¬†When they approached Jerusalem, they came to Bethsphage and Bethany at the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples 2¬†and said to them, ‚ÄúGo your way into the‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†When they approached Jerusalem, they came to Bethsphage and Bethany at the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples 2¬†and said to them, ‚ÄúGo your way into the village that is opposite you. Immediately as you enter into it, you will find a young donkey tied, on which no one has sat. Untie him and bring him. 3¬†If anyone asks you, ‚ÄòWhy are you doing this?‚Äô say, ‚ÄòThe Lord needs him;‚Äô and immediately he will send him back here.‚Äù 4¬†They went away, and found a young donkey tied at the door outside in the open street, and they untied him. 5¬†Some of those who stood there asked them, ‚ÄúWhat are you doing, untying the young donkey?‚Äù 6¬†They said to them just as Jesus had said, and they let them go. 7¬†They brought the young donkey to Jesus and threw their garments on it, and Jesus sat on it. 8¬†Many spread their garments on the way, and others were cutting down branches from the trees and spreading them on the road. 9¬†Those who went in front and those who followed cried out, ‚ÄúHosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord! 10¬†Blessed is the kingdom of our father David that is coming in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest!‚Äù 11¬†Jesus entered into the temple in Jerusalem. When he had looked around at everything, because it was evening he left Jerusalem and returned to Bethany with the twelve. 12¬†The next day, when they had left Bethany‚Äôs town boundaries he was hungry. 13¬†Seeing a fig tree far away off having leaves, he came to see if perhaps he might find anything on it. When he came to it, he found nothing but leaves, for it was not the season for figs. 14¬†Jesus told it, ‚ÄúMay no one ever eat fruit from you again!‚Äù and his disciples heard it. 15¬†They came to Jerusalem, and Jesus entered into the temple and began to throw out those who sold and those who bought in the temple, and overthrew the money changers‚Äô tables and the seats of those who sold the doves. 16¬†He would not allow anyone to carry merchandise through the temple. 17¬†He taught, saying to them, ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it written, ‚ÄòMy house will be called a house of prayer for all the nations?‚Äô But you have made it a den of robbers!‚Äù 18¬†The chief priests and the scribes heard it, and searched for how they could destroy him. For they feared him because all the great crowd was amazed at his teaching. 19¬†When evening came, he went out of the city. 20¬†As they passed by in the morning, they saw the fig tree withered away from the roots. 21¬†Peter, remembering, said to him, ‚ÄúRabbi, look! The fig tree which you cursed has withered away.‚Äù 22¬†Jesus answered them, ‚ÄúHave expectant trustfaith in God. 23¬†For most certainly I tell you, whoever may tell this mountain, ‚ÄòBe taken up and cast into the sea,‚Äô and doesn‚Äôt doubt in his heart, but believes that what he says is happening, he shall have whatever he says. 24¬†Therefore I tell you, all things whatever you pray and ask for, believe that you have received them, and you shall have them. 25¬†Whenever you stand praying, forgive, if you have anything against anyone; so that your Father, who is in heaven, may also forgive you your wrongdoings. 26¬†But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father in heaven forgive your wrongdoings.‚Äù 27¬†They came again to Jerusalem, and as he was walking in the temple, the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders came to him, 28¬†and they began saying to him, ‚ÄúBy what authority do you do these things? Or who gave you this authority to do these things?‚Äù 29¬†Jesus said to them, ‚ÄúI will ask you one question. Answer me, and I will tell you by what authority I do these things. 30¬†The baptism of John‚Äîwas it from heaven, or from men? Answer me.‚Äù 31¬†They reasoned with themselves, saying, ‚ÄúIf we should say, ‚ÄòFrom heaven;‚Äô he will say, ‚ÄòWhy then did you not believe him?‚Äô 32¬†If we should say, ‚ÄòFrom men‚Äô‚Äú‚Äîthey feared the people, for all held John to really be a prophet. 33¬†They answered Jesus, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know.‚Äù Jesus said to them, ‚ÄúNeither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.‚Äù Ôªø

item.title: Mark 12
item.description: 1¬†He began to speak to them in object lessons. ‚ÄúA man planted a vineyard, put a hedge around it, dug a pit for the wine press, built a tower, rented it out to a farmer‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†He began to speak to them in object lessons. ‚ÄúA man planted a vineyard, put a hedge around it, dug a pit for the wine press, built a tower, rented it out to a farmer, and went into another country. 2¬†When it was time, he sent a servant to the farmer to get from the farmer his share of the fruit of the vineyard. 3¬†They took him, beat him, and sent him away empty. 4¬†Again, he sent another servant to them; and they threw stones at him, wounded him in the head, and sent him away shamefully treated. 5¬†Again he sent another, and they killed him, and many others, beating some, and killing some. 6¬†Therefore still having one, his beloved son, he sent him last to them, saying, ‚ÄòThey will respect my son.‚Äô 7¬†But those farmers said among themselves, ‚ÄòThis is the heir. Come, let‚Äôs kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.‚Äô 8¬†They took him, killed him, and cast him out of the vineyard. 9¬†What therefore will the lord of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the farmers, and will give the vineyard to others. 10¬†Haven‚Äôt you even read this Scripture: ‚ÄòThe stone which the builders rejected was made the head of the corner. * 11¬†This was from the Lord. It is marvelous in our eyes‚Äô?‚Äú* 12¬†They tried to seize him, but they feared the great crowd; for they perceived that he spoke the object lesson against them. They left him and went away. 13¬†They sent some of the Pharisees and the Herodians to him, that they might trap him with words. 14¬†When they had come, they asked him, ‚ÄúTeacher, we know that you are honest, and don‚Äôt defer to anyone; for you aren‚Äôt partial to anyone, but truly teach the way of God. Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar, or not? 15¬†Shall we give, or shall we not give?‚Äù But he, knowing their hypocrisy, said to them, ‚ÄúWhy do you test me? Bring me Roman coin (a denarius), that I may see it.‚Äù 16¬†They brought it. He said to them, ‚ÄúWhose is this image and inscription?‚Äù They said to him, ‚ÄúCaesar‚Äôs.‚Äù 17¬†Jesus answered them, ‚ÄúGive Caesar the things that are Caesar‚Äôs, and to God the things that are God‚Äôs.‚Äù They were greatly amazed at him. 18¬†Some Sadducees, who say that there is no resurrection, came to him. They asked him, saying, 19¬†‚ÄúTeacher, Moses wrote to us, ‚ÄòIf a man‚Äôs brother dies and leaves a wife behind him, and leaves no children, that his brother should take his wife and raise up offspring for his brother.‚Äô 20¬†There were seven brothers. The first took a wife, and dying left no offspring. 21¬†The second took her, and died, leaving no children behind him. The third likewise; 22¬†and the seven took her and left no children. Last of all the woman also died. 23¬†In the resurrection, when they rise, whose wife will she be of them? For the seven had her as a wife.‚Äù 24¬†Jesus answered them, ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt this because you are mistaken, not knowing the Scriptures nor the power of God? 25¬†For when they will rise from the dead, they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in heaven. 26¬†But about the dead, that they are raised: haven‚Äôt you read in the book of Moses in the story about the burning bush, how God spoke to him, saying, ‚ÄòI am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob‚Äô? 27¬†He is not the God of the dead, but of the living. You are badly mistaken!‚Äù 28¬†One of the scribes came and heard them questioning together, and knowing that he had answered them well, asked him, ‚ÄúWhich commandment is the greatest of all?‚Äù 29¬†Jesus answered, ‚ÄúThe greatest is: ‚ÄòHear, Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one. * 30¬†You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your mind, and with all your strength.‚Äô* This is the first commandment. 31¬†The second is like this: ‚ÄòYou shall love your neighbor as yourself.‚Äô There is no other commandment greater than these.‚Äù 32¬†The scribe said to him, ‚ÄúTruly, teacher, you have said well that he is one, and there is none other but he; 33¬†and to love him with all the heart, with all the understanding, all the soul, and with all the strength, and to love his neighbor as himself, is more important than all whole burnt offerings and sacrifices.‚Äù 34¬†When Jesus saw that he answered wisely, he said to him, ‚ÄúYou are not far from God‚Äôs Kingdom.‚Äù No one dared ask him any question after that. 35¬†Jesus responded as he taught in the temple, ‚ÄúHow is it that the scribes say that the Messiah is the son of David? 36¬†For David himself said in the Holy Spirit, ‚ÄòThe Lord said to my Lord, ‚ÄúSit at my right hand, until I make your enemies the footstool of your feet.‚Äú‚Äô 37¬†Therefore David himself calls him Lord, so how can he be his son?‚Äù The common people heard him gladly. 38¬†In his teaching he said to them, ‚ÄúBeware of the scribes, who like to walk in long robes, and to be greeted in the marketplaces, 39¬†and to have the best seats in the synagogues and the best places at feasts, 40¬†those who devour widows‚Äô houses, and for a pretense make long prayers. These will receive greater condemnation.‚Äù 41¬†Jesus sat down opposite the treasury and saw how the great crowd cast money into the treasury. Many who were rich cast in much. 42¬†A poor widow came and she cast in two small brass coins (which equal a quadrans coin). 43¬†Jesus called his disciples close and said to them, ‚ÄúWith certainty I tell you, this poor widow gave more than all those who are giving into the treasury, 44¬†for they all gave out of their abundance, but she, out of her poverty, gave all that she had to live on.‚Äù Ôªø

item.title: Mark 13
item.description: 1¬†As he went out of the temple, one of his disciples said to him, ‚ÄúTeacher, see what kind of stones and what kind of buildings!‚Äù 2¬†Jesus said to him, ‚ÄúDo you see these‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†As he went out of the temple, one of his disciples said to him, ‚ÄúTeacher, see what kind of stones and what kind of buildings!‚Äù 2¬†Jesus said to him, ‚ÄúDo you see these great buildings? There will not be left here one stone on another, which will not be thrown down.‚Äù 3¬†As he sat on the Mount of Olives opposite the temple, Peter, James, John, and Andrew asked him privately, 4¬†‚ÄúTell us, when will these things happen? What is the sign that these things are all about to be fulfilled?‚Äù 5¬†Jesus replied, ‚ÄúBe careful that no one misleads you. 6¬†For many will come in my name, saying, ‚ÄòI am he!‚Äô and will mislead many. 7¬†‚ÄúWhen you hear of wars and rumors of wars, don‚Äôt be troubled. For those must happen, but the end is not yet. 8¬†For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. There will be earthquakes in various places. There will be famines and troubles. These things are the beginning of birth pains. 9¬†‚ÄúBut watch yourselves, for they will deliver you up to councils. You will be beaten in synagogues. You will stand before rulers and kings for my sake, for a testimony to them. 10¬†The Good News must first be declared to all the nations. 11¬†When they lead you away and deliver you up, don‚Äôt be anxious beforehand or premeditate what you will say, but say whatever will be given you in that hour. For it is not you who speak, but the Holy Spirit. 12¬†‚ÄúBrother will deliver up brother to death, and the father his child. Children will rise up against parents and cause them to be put to death. 13¬†You will be hated by all men for my name‚Äôs sake, but he who endures to the end will be saved. 14¬†‚ÄúBut when you see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing where it ought not‚Äù (let the reader understand), ‚Äúthen let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, 15¬†and let the person on the housetop not go down, enter, or take anything out of his house. 16¬†The person out in the field must not return even to get his coat. 17¬†How terrible it will be for women who are pregnant or who nurse babies in those days! 18¬†Pray that your escape won‚Äôt be in the winter. 19¬†For in those days there will be oppression unlike anyone has known from the earliest beginning of God‚Äôs creation until now. And it will never will be that great again. 20¬†Unless the Lord had shortened the days, nobody would have been saved. But for the sake of the chosen ones‚Äîwhom the Lord himself picked out‚Äîhe shortened the days. 21¬†Then if anyone tells you, ‚ÄòLook, here is the Messiah!‚Äô or, ‚ÄòLook, there!‚Äô don‚Äôt believe it. 22¬†For false ‚Äúmessiahs‚Äù and false ‚Äúprophets‚Äù will arise, will show signs and wonders, and will try to lead‚Äîif possible‚Äîeven the chosen ones down their false and corrupt path. 23¬†But you watch. ‚ÄúLook! I have told you about all these things beforehand. 24¬†But in those days, after that oppression, *the sun will be darkened, the moon will not give its light, * 25¬†the stars will be falling from the sky, and the powers that are in the heavens will be shaken. 26¬†Then they will see the Son of Man coming in clouds with great power and glory. 27¬†Then he will send out his angels, and will gather together his chosen ones from the four winds, from the ends of the earth to the ends of the sky. 28¬†‚ÄúNow learn this object lesson from the fig tree: When its branch becomes tender and produces its leaves, you know that its summer is near; 29¬†even so you also, when you see these things happening, know that your summer is near, at the doors. 30¬†Most certainly I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all these things happen. 31¬†Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away. 32¬†‚ÄúBut of that day or that hour no one knows‚Äînot even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father. 33¬†Watch, keep alert, and pray; for you don‚Äôt know when the time is. 34¬†‚ÄúIt is like a man traveling to another country, having left his house and given authority to each of his servants to do his work, and having also commanded the doorkeeper to keep watch. 35¬†Therefore watch, for you don‚Äôt know when the lord of the house is coming‚Äîwhether at evening, at midnight, when the rooster crows, or in the morning; 36¬†Otherwise when he comes suddenly he might find you sleeping. 37¬†What I tell you, I tell all: Watch!‚Äù Ôªø

item.title: Mark 14
item.description: 1¬†It was now two days before the Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread, and the chief priests and the scribes sought how they might seize him by deception and kill‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†It was now two days before the Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread, and the chief priests and the scribes sought how they might seize him by deception and kill him. 2¬†For they said, ‚ÄúNot during the feast, because there might be a riot among the people.‚Äù 3¬†Meanwhile Jesus was in Bethany in the house of Simon (a man who previously had been a leper). As Jesus sat, eating at the table, a woman came having a beautiful alabaster jar of expensive aromatic oil made using pure nard. She broke the jar and poured it over his head. 4¬†But there were some who were indignant among themselves, saying, ‚ÄúWhy has this expensive perfumed oil been wasted? 5¬†For this might have been sold for more than three hundred denarii (an entire year‚Äôs wages) and given to the poor!‚Äù So they criticized her. 6¬†But Jesus said, ‚ÄúLeave her alone. Why do you trouble her? She has done a good work for me. 7¬†For you always have the poor with you, and whenever you want to, you can do them good; but you will not always have me. 8¬†She has done what she could and has anointed my body for burial ahead of time. 9¬†With certainty I tell you, wherever this Good News is declared throughout the whole world, what this woman has done will be remembered and retold in memory of her.‚Äù 10¬†Then Judas Iscariot, who was one of the twelve, found to the chief priests in order to discuss how he could betray Jesus to them. 11¬†For their part, when they heard this, they were glad and promised to give him money. And Judas began searching for an opportune moment to betray Jesus. 12¬†On the first day of unleavened bread, when they sacrificed the Passover, his disciples asked him, ‚ÄúWhere do you want us to go and prepare that you may eat the Passover?‚Äù 13¬†He sent two of his disciples and said to them, ‚ÄúEnter the city, and a man carrying a pitcher of water will meet you. Follow him, 14¬†and wherever he enters, tell the master of the house, ‚ÄòThe Teacher says, ‚ÄúWhere is the guest room, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?‚Äú‚Äô 15¬†He will himself show you a large upper room furnished and ready. Make preparations there.‚Äù 16¬†Jesus‚Äôs disciples entered the city and found things exactly the way Jesus had told them, and they prepared the Passover. 17¬†When it was evening he arrived with the twelve. 18¬†As they at the table eating, Jesus said, ‚ÄúWith certainty I tell you, one of you will betray me‚Äîeven one who eats with me here.‚Äù 19¬†They became full of grief, and began to ask him one by one, ‚ÄúSurely not I?‚Äù And another said, ‚ÄúSurely not I?‚Äù 20¬†Jesus answered, ‚ÄúIt is one of you twelve who eats from this dish along with me. 21¬†For the Son of Man must die in the same way as it was written in the Scriptures. But intense grieving misery will come to that man who betrays the Son of Man! It would be better for that man if he had not been born.‚Äù 22¬†As they were eating, Jesus took bread, and when he had blessed it, he broke it and gave to them, and said, ‚ÄúTake, eat. This is my body.‚Äù 23¬†He took the cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave to them. They all drank of it. 24¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúThis is my blood of the new covenant, which is poured out for many. 25¬†With certainty I tell you, I will never drink of the fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it again in God‚Äôs Kingdom.‚Äù 26¬†When they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives. 27¬†Jesus said to them, ‚ÄúAll of you will be made to stumble because of me tonight, for it is written, ‚ÄòI will strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.‚Äô 28¬†However, after I am raised up, I will go before you into Galilee.‚Äù 29¬†But Peter said to him, ‚ÄúEven if all other people desert you, I will not.‚Äù 30¬†Jesus said to him, ‚ÄúWith certainty I tell you that you today that even this night‚Äîbefore the rooster crows twice‚Äîyou will deny me three times.‚Äù 31¬†But Peter protested all the more, ‚ÄúIf I must die with you, I will not deny you!‚Äù They all vowed the same thing. 32¬†They came to a place which was named Gethsemane. He said to his disciples, ‚ÄúSit here while I pray.‚Äù 33¬†He took with him Peter, James, and John, and became greatly troubled and distressed. 34¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúMy heart grieves so deeply‚Äîeven to the point of death! Stay here with me and watch.‚Äù 35¬†He went forward a little, and fell to the ground, and prayed that if it were possible, the terrible hour prepared for him might pass him by. 36¬†He prayed, ‚ÄúDaddy! Father! All things are possible to you. Please remove this cup from me. However, not what I desire, but what you desire.‚Äù 37¬†He came back and finding them sleeping said to Peter, ‚ÄúSimon, are you sleeping? Couldn‚Äôt you watch one hour? 38¬†Watch and pray, that you may not enter into temptation. The spirit is very willing, but ‚Äòhuman strength‚Äô is weak.‚Äù 39¬†Again he went away and prayed, saying the same words. 40¬†Again he returned and found them sleeping, for their eyes were very heavy; and they didn‚Äôt know how to reply to him. 41¬†He came the third time and said to them, ‚ÄúSleep on now, and take your rest. It is enough. The time has come. Look! the Son of Man is being betrayed into the power of evil people. 42¬†Get up! Let‚Äôs get going. Look! The one who is betraying me has arrived.‚Äù 43¬†Immediately, while he was still speaking, Judas, one of the twelve, came‚Äîand with him a great crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders. 44¬†Now the one who betrayed Jesus had told them to watch for this signal: He said, ‚ÄúWhoever I kiss, he is the one. Arrest him and lead him away safely.‚Äù 45¬†When Judas arrived, immediately he came up to Jesus and said, ‚ÄúRabbi! Rabbi!‚Äù and kissed him. 46¬†They grabbed him and seized him. 47¬†But a person who stood by drew his sword, struck the servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear. 48¬†Jesus answered them, ‚ÄúHave you come as if you were chasing a robber and needed swords and clubs to seize me? 49¬†I was with you in the temple every day teaching, and you didn‚Äôt arrest me. But this has happened so that the Scriptures could be fulfilled.‚Äù 50¬†They all his disciples abandoned him and fled. 51¬†A certain young man followed him and all he was weaaring was a linen cloth thrown around his naked body. The mob grabbed him! 52¬†But he left the linen cloth and fled from them naked. 53¬†They led Jesus away to the high priest‚Äôs house where all the chief priests, elders, and scribes were joining them. 54¬†Peter had followed Jesus from a distance, until he came into the courtyard of the high priest‚Äôs home. He sat along with the officers, warming himself in the light of the fire. 55¬†Now the chief priests and the whole council searched for witnesses who could testify against Jesus so they could put him to death. But they couldn‚Äôt find any 56¬†because although many people gave false testimony against him, their stories didn‚Äôt agree with each other! 57¬†Some stood before those assembled and offered this false testimony against Jesus: 58¬†‚ÄúWe heard him say, ‚ÄòI will destroy this temple that is made with hands, and in three days I will build another made without hands.‚Äô‚Äù 59¬†But they even disagreed in their testimony about this! 60¬†Finally the high priest stood up in the middle of the assembly and asked Jesus, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have anything to say? How will you respond to these accusations against you?‚Äù 61¬†But he stayed quiet, and didn‚Äôt answer. Again the high priest asked Jesus, ‚ÄúAre you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One?‚Äù 62¬†Jesus said, ‚ÄúI Am. And you will see the Son of Man sitting in the seat of highest power and authority and coming with the clouds of the sky.‚Äù 63¬†The high priest tore his clothes and said, ‚ÄúDo we need witnesses any longer? 64¬†You have heard him defaming God by claiming to be God himself! What do you think?‚Äù They unanimously declared Jesus guilty, fully deserving death. 65¬†Some began to spit on him, to cover his face, to beat him with fists, and to order him, ‚ÄúProphesy!‚Äù Then the officers struck him with the palms of their hands. 66¬†As Peter was in the courtyard below, one of the maids of the high priest came. 67¬†When she noticed Peter warming himself, she looked intently at him and said, ‚ÄúYou were also with the Nazarene, Jesus!‚Äù 68¬†But he denied it! ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know or understand what you are saying‚Äù, Peter answered. He went out on the porch, and the rooster crowed. 69¬†The maid saw him on the porch and insisted again to the other onlookers, ‚ÄúThis man is one of them!‚Äù 70¬†But Peter again denied it! And just a little bit later those who were milling around said to Peter, ‚ÄúYou must be one of them because you are from Galilee! Your accent gives you away!‚Äù 71¬†But Peter began to curse and to swear, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know this man you‚Äôre talking about!‚Äù 72¬†Then the rooster crowed the second time. Peter remembered that Jesus had told him, ‚ÄúBefore the rooster crows twice, you will deny me three times.‚Äù And Peter broke down weeping. Ôªø

item.title: Mark 16
item.description: 1¬†When the Sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought spices, that they might come and anoint him. 2¬†Very early on the first day‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded: 1¬†When the Sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought spices, that they might come and anoint him. 2¬†Very early on the first day of the week, they came to the tomb when the sun had risen. 3¬†They were saying among themselves, ‚ÄúWho will roll away the stone from the door of the tomb for us?‚Äù 4¬†for it was very big. Looking up, they saw that the stone was rolled back. 5¬†Entering into the tomb, they saw a young man sitting on the right side, dressed in a white robe; and they were amazed. 6¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be amazed. You seek Jesus, the Nazarene, who has been crucified. He has risen! He is not here. See the place where they laid him! 7¬†But go, tell his disciples and Peter, ‚ÄòHe goes before you into Galilee. There you will see him, as he said to you.‚Äô‚Äù 8¬†They went out, and fled from the tomb, for trembling and astonishment had come on them. They said nothing to anyone; for they were afraid. 9¬†Now when he had risen early on the first day of the week, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven demons. 10¬†She went and told those who had been with him, as they mourned and wept. 11¬†When they heard that he was alive and had been seen by her, they disbelieved. 12¬†After these things he was revealed in another form to two of them as they walked, on their way into the country. 13¬†They went away and told it to the rest. They didn‚Äôt believe them, either. 14¬†Afterward he was revealed to the eleven themselves as they sat at the table; and he reprimanded them for their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they didn‚Äôt believe those who had seen him after he had risen. 15¬†He said to them, ‚ÄúGo into all the world and declare the Good News to the whole creation. 16¬†He who believes and is baptized will be saved; but he who disbelieves will be condemned. 17¬†These signs will accompany those who believe: in my name they will cast out demons; they will speak with new languages; 18¬†they will take up serpents; and if they drink any deadly thing, it will in no way hurt them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover.‚Äù 19¬†So then the Lord, after he had spoken to them, was received up into heaven and sat down at the right hand of God. 20¬†They went out and spoke God‚Äôs word everywhere, the Lord working with them and confirming the word by the signs that followed. Amen.

item.content:encoded: 1¬†Immediately in the morning the chief priests with the elders, scribes, and the whole council consulted together, bound Jesus, carried him away, and transferred him as a prisoner to Pilate. Pilate was the region‚Äôs Roman governor. 2¬†Pilate asked Jesus, ‚ÄúAre you the King of the Jews?‚Äù He answered, ‚ÄúSo you say.‚Äù 3¬†The chief priests accused him of many crimes. 4¬†Pilate asked him again, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have any answers for them? They are accusing you of many crimes!‚Äù 5¬†Jesus didn‚Äôt answer. And Pilate was amazed. 6¬†Now at the feast Pilate customarily pardoned and released one prisoner‚Äîone who they requested by name. 7¬†And Pilate was holding an insurgent named Barabbas (his name means ‚ÄúSon of the Father‚Äù) along with others who rebelled along with him. They were all murderers. 8¬†The great crowd roared loudly for Pilate to release a prisoner as he customarily did during the feast. 9¬†Pilate answered, ‚ÄúDo you want me to release to you the King of the Jews?‚Äù 10¬†(because Pilate sensed that the chief priests had really arrested Jesus because they were jealous of him). 11¬†But the chief priests riled up the mob so that they all demanded that Pilate release Barabbas to them instead. 12¬†Pilate responded, ‚ÄúThen what should I do to the man you call the King of the Jews?‚Äù 13¬†They roared back, ‚ÄúCrucify him!‚Äù 14¬†Pilate said to them, ‚ÄúWhy? What crime did he commit?‚Äù But they roared back even louder, ‚ÄúCrucify him!‚Äù 15¬†Pilate wanted to appease the mob, so he released Barabbas to them. And after he flogged Jesus with a lead-tipped whip, Pilate released him to Roman soldiers to be crucified. 16¬†The soldiers led Jesus away to the great courtyard (named the Praetorium), then called for the entire regiment. 17¬†The regiment clothed Jesus in royal purple, weaved a crown made of thorns, and pressed it on his head. 18¬†They saluteed and taunted him, saying ‚ÄúHail, King of the Jews!‚Äù 19¬†They struck his head with a stick that came from a reed. They spat on him. And bowing their knees, they ‚Äúpaid homage‚Äù to him. 20¬†When they had mocked him in these ways, they took the purple robe off him and dressed him in his own clothes. And the soldiers led Jesus out to crucify him. 21¬†On the way, the soldiers chose a man who happened to be passing by on his way from the country (Simon of Cyrene, the father of Alexander and Rufus). They forced him to join them and carry Jesus‚Äôs cross. 22¬†They brought Jesus to the place called Golgotha. This name means, ‚ÄúPlace of the skull.‚Äù 23¬†The soldiers offered him wine drugged with myrrh, but Jesus wouldn‚Äôt drink it. 24¬†They crucified Jesus‚Äîthey nailed him to a cross. And they gambled together to decide who would get each piece of his clothes. 25¬†It was the third hour‚Äîabout 9 o‚Äôclock‚Äîwhen they crucified Jesus. 26¬†A sign with his crime was fastened above him. It read, ‚ÄúTHE KING OF THE JEWS.‚Äù 27¬†Along with Jesus, the soldiers crucified two robbers‚Äîone on his right hand, and one to his left. 28¬†[This fulfilled the Scripture that says, ‚ÄúHe was counted alongside those who live lawlessly.‚Äù] 29¬†Those who passed by defamed him, shook their heads and hurled insults, ‚ÄúHa! You who destroy the temple and build it in three days, 30¬†save yourself! Come down from the cross!‚Äù 31¬†Similarly, the chief priests mocked him among themselves and with the scribes. They said, ‚ÄúHe saved others. He can‚Äôt save himself! 32¬†Let the Messiah, the King of Israel, now come down from the cross, that we may see and believe him.‚Äù Those who were crucified with him also insulted him. 33¬†When the sixth hour had come (about noon), there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour, or approximately 3 P.M. 34¬†At the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, ‚ÄúEloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?‚Äù which means, *‚ÄúMy God, my God, why have you forsaken me?‚Äù * 35¬†Some stood by heard this and said, ‚ÄúLook! he is calling Elijah.‚Äù 36¬†One ran and filled a sponge full of vinegar. He put it on the end of a stick and offered it to Jesus to drink, saying, ‚ÄúLeave him alone. Let‚Äôs see whether Elijah comes to take him down!‚Äù 37¬†Jesus cried out with a loud voice, and breathed his last breath. 38¬†The temple curtain (that separated the Most Holy Place from the rest) was torn in two from the top to the bottom. 39¬†When the Roman centurion standing guard saw that Jesus cried out like this and then breathed his last breath, he said, ‚ÄúThis man really was God‚Äôs Son!‚Äù 40¬†There were women watching from far away including Mary Magdalene, Mary (the mother of James the Younger and of Joseph), and Salome. 41¬†When Jesus was in Galilee, these women travelled with him and supported him. Also, many other women who came to Jerusalem with Jesus were there. 42¬†When evening arrived, because it was the Preparation Day‚Äîthat is, the day before the Sabbath‚Äî 43¬†Joseph of Arimathaea boldly went to Pilate, and asked for Jesus‚Äô body. (Joseph was a prominent council member who was also looking for God‚Äôs Kingdom.) 44¬†Pilate was surprised to hear that Jesus was already dead; and summoning the centurion, he asked him whether Jesus had been dead long. 45¬†After discussing this with the centurion, he granted Jesus‚Äôs body to Joseph. 46¬†Joseph bought a linen cloth, and taking him down, wound him in the linen cloth and laid him in a tomb which had been cut out of a rock. He rolled a stone against the door of the tomb. 47¬†Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses, saw where he was laid. Ôªø
